topic:
Airport Security

A relevant document would discuss how effective government orders to better scrutinize passengers and luggage on international flights and to step up screening of all carry-on baggage has been.  

A relevant document would contain reports on what new steps airports worldwide have taken to better scrutinize passengers and their luggage on international flights and to step up screening of all carry-on baggage.  With the increase in international terrorism and in the wake of the TWA Flight 800 disaster, articles on airport security relating in particular to additional steps taken by airports to increase flight safety would be relevant.  The mere mention of enhanced security does not constitute relevance.  Additional steps refer to something beyond just passenger and carry-on screening using the normal methods. Examples of new steps would be additional personnel, sophisticated monitoring and screening devices, and extraordinary measures to check luggage in the baggage compartment.


You are a classifier for "airport security screening enhancements" on international flights.

RELEVANT if **ANY** of these hold:

- The document names a specific airport or country and describes new measures implemented (e. g. additional personnel, sophisticated monitoring and screening devices, etc.) beyond just passenger and carry-on screening using the normal methods
- It explains how these measures differ from the usual screening procedures
- It reports on outcomes, effectiveness, or evaluations of these measures

NON-RELEVANT if any of these hold:

- It only refers to standard passenger or carry-on screening methods
- It discusses airport security in general terms or policy announcements without relating to additional steps to increase flight safety.
- It covers the TWA Flight 800 incident background without linking to post-incident screening improvements.

NEGATIVE Example:
Title: "Airports Ramp Up Metal-Detector Checks After TWA 800"
relevant: false
justification: "Mentions standard metal-detector use but no new measures beyond existing procedures."

POSITIVE Example:
Title: "London Heathrow Deploys 3D CT Scanners for All Carry-On Bags"
relevant: true
justification: "Airport: Heathrow; New measures: 3D CT baggage scanners replacing X-ray; Outcomes: 30 % increase in explosive detection rates with minimal delay."

results.content:
1996-09-18 
 New Measures Taken to Improve Security at Airports 


NEW PORT, September 17 (Xinhua) -- The Port Authority of New
York and New Jersey, which is responsible for the administration
of airports, has taken new measures to improve security at all
three major airports in the region--Kennedy International Airport,
Newark Airport and Laguardia Airport.


Under the new measures, all airport security workers will be
required to obtain identification badges from the Port
Authority;there will be a 10 year employment history check for
anyone hired to operate baggage screening machines; outside
experts are being hired to review airport security on a regular
basis, both at areas controlled by the Port Authority and areas
under control of the airlines; teams of bomb-detecting dogs are
being established to patrol airport grounds and terminals.


The comprehensive upgrade of all aspects of security at the
airports is in response to the repeated criticisms of security at
Kennedy International Airport after the crash of a Trans World
Airlines flight which exploded moments after taking off from
Kennedy Airport on July 17, this year.


While a cause of the explosion has not been officially
determined, investigators believe that the ill-fated Boeing 747
was brought down by a bomb hidden in the passenger cabin. So,
Airport security has been a subject of heightened national
concern. Last week, U.S. President Bill Clinton asked Congress for
about 250 million u.s. dollars in new spending for a variety of
measures to improve security at airports nationwide.

1996-03-01 16:28 
 Washington Lifts Warning on Manila Airport 


MANILA, March 1 (Xinhua) -- The US Federal Aviation Authority
(FAA) has lifted the warning on alleged deficiencies in security
measures at the Ninoy Aquino International Airport (NAIA) in US
airports.


Philippine Transpiration and Communications Secretary Jesus
Garcia, Jr. said today that the lifting of the warning was
conveyed to him by US Transportation Secretary Federico Pena.


The warning was posted in US airports last August following
findings by the FAA that "security measures at the NAIA were not
effective."


Last month, an FAA team completed their reassessment of the
NAIA security measures and found them at par with standards of the
International Civil Aviation Organization.

results.content:
1998-08-24 12:36 
 Israel Tightens Security in All Airports 


JERUSALEM, August 24 (Xinhua) -- Israel on Monday tightened
security in all airports where international airlines are landing
and taking off in a bid to prevent terrorist attacks.


Israel Radio said the measure was taken after receiving the
warning issued by militant Islamic groups that they would attack
U.S. and Israeli airports and other strategic places, including
bombing foreign airlines in Israel, to avenge the U.S. missile
attacks on Sudan and Afghanistan.


Last Thursday, the U.S. launched cruise missile strikes at
suspected targets of Islamic militants in Sudan and Afghanistan,
who were believed to have carried out the August 7 twin bombings
of U.S. embassies in Kenya and Tanzania that killed over 250
people and wounded 5,000 others.


Israel, the closest ally for the U.S., is one of a few
countries that have voiced strong support to the strikes. But most
of the Arab and Islamic countries gave denounced or expressed
reservation over the U.S. air strikes, terming them as provocative
actions against the Muslims.


At the busy Ben Gurion International Airport, security checks
were beefed up while all baggage were searched thoroughly. All
passengers, particularly those from Arab and Islamic countries,
were strictly questioned by the airport security staff.


Israeli Airport Authority said that the security measures had
also been taken for foreign airlines at the airport.


Meanwhile, Israel is taking preventive security measures at
all strategic targets in the country to prevent possible
terrorist attacks.

results.content:
Israel increases security at airports following threats


	   LOD, Israel (AP) _ Israel is adding security personnel at its
international airport in response to threats by Islamic militants
to attack Israeli and U.S. targets, including airlines, officials
said Monday.
	   Threats against U.S. and Israeli targets emerged after last
week's U.S. air strikes in Sudan and Afghanistan that were aimed at
Osama bin Laden, a Saudi millionaire and Islamic militant linked to
the bombings of two U.S. embassies in East Africa this month.
	   On Sunday, a leading Muslim activist close to bin Laden said
Islamic militants are preparing to retaliate for the air strikes by
targeting U.S. and Israeli strategic sites and airliners.
	   Pini Shis, a spokesman for Israel's Airport Authority, said more
security workers had been added at Ben Gurion International Airport
near Tel Aviv, and that security was also being tightened at
airfields in Eilat and Tel Aviv.
	   ``Since the American activity in Afghanistan and Sudan, security
measures have been increased in Israeli airports,'' Shis told The
Associated Press. He would not specify what other measures had been
taken.
	   Israel radio said cars entering Ben Gurion airport were being
checked more closely and some delays were reported in getting into
the airport.
	   But reporters at the scene said they did not notice longer lines
at the police checkpoints near the airport.
	   An Israeli tour guide who passes through the airport often said
his group did not notice any real differences in security on
Monday. ``Security appears to have been stepped up behind the
scenes if you know where to look,'' said the guide, Ilan Bar.
	   In a related development, the Haaretz daily said that metal
detectors at Ben Gurion do not pick up certain items that contain
metal, including kitchen knives and big key chains.
	   Haaretz tested the five metal detectors in the departure hall
twice and found that the equipment did not pick up on metal items
weighing about 350 grams, or a little over half a pound.
	   Shis said security officials are aware that metal detectors
cannot alert security to every metal object.
	   ``Metal detectors are not the final answer in preventing terror
attacks,'' Shis told The Associated Press. ``The machines are only
one link in an entire chain of security measures.''
	   Shis would not specify which other means are used to check if a
person is carrying weapons.
	   Security measures at Ben Gurion are among the most stringent
worldwide. Motorists are stopped at checkpoints at the airport
entrances, with some passengers _ generally Palestinians _ being
questioned there and having their luggage checked.
	   In the departure lounge, tourists, Palestinians and Israeli Arab
citizens are questioned at length, while Jewish Israelis usually
undergo only a perfunctory check.
 &UR; str-lc/kl

results.content:
2000-01-28 
 Nepal to Improve Security at Int'l Airport 


KATHMANDU, January 27 (Xinhua) -- Minister for Tourism and
Aviation Bijaya Gachchhedar said Thursday that Nepal will take
short- and long-term measures to strengthen the security system at
the Tribhuvan International Airport.


Gachchhedar told a press conference that the short-term
measures would be implemented immediately and long-term measures
would be implemented gradually.


He said immediate steps would be taken to categorize the pass
system and make it systematic, improve X-ray machines and install
new metal detectors.


Shops would not be set up beyond the security checking area,
special training would be provided to security personnel and
employees, strict rules would be implemented for people to go to
the VIP lounge, and special areas would be allocated for the
passengers, he added.


He said these measures are recommended in a report submitted
Monday to the government by an investigation committee related to
the hijacking incident. An Indian Airlines passenger jet was
hijacked on December 24 on route from Kathmandu to New Delhi.

results.content:
1999-03-14 19:21:47 
 usa 
 Suspicious Bag at Airport Probed 


	COLUMBUS, Ohio (AP) -- The FBI is investigating whether former  
federal transportation inspector general Mary Schiavo violated any 
laws when she checked a suspicious bag at an airport here to test 
security measures, officials said Sunday. 


	Ms. Schiavo, a former inspector general of the Department of  
Transportation, checked a bag Friday at Port Columbus International 
Airport as part of a story WCMH-TV was doing on airport security. 


	The station showed the contents of her bag, which included what  
appeared to be a tape recorder, an alarm clock and wiring. Ms. 
Schiavo said the bag contained several items, including a cellular 
phone wire. 


	Airport officials said a suspicious bag had been spotted and was  
not placed on the flight, but it declined to say whether the bag 
belonged to Ms. Schiavo. 


	``Currently we're investigating to determine if any law was  
violated,'' FBI spokesman Frank Scafidi said Sunday. 


	Paul Takemoto, FAA spokesman, said that the Federal Aviation  
Administration was looking into whether its regulations were 
violated in any way. 


	The bag's discovery led to a shutdown of a runway for four hours  
Friday, but no flights were delayed. 


	Ms. Schiavo said Sunday that she bought a ticket to Washington,  
D.C., and checked her bag with America West Airlines, but did not 
board the flight. She said she was hoping to determine whether the 
bag would be allowed to take off with the flight even though its 
owner was not on board. 


	As a security measure on international flights, bags are matched  
to passengers. Such checks are not required for domestic 
passengers. 


	``If that is indeed what happened, then I'm glad. That's an  
improvement,'' Ms. Schiavo said when told the bag was held from the 
flight. ``I'm very sorry that people were inconvenienced, but I did 
not cause that.'' 


	Ms. Schiavo resigned from her federal post in 1996 after  
criticizing the FAA on several occasions. Since then she has 
published a book accusing the FAA of sloppy inspections, lax 
airport security and disregard for bogus airplane parts.

results.content:
Security stepped up at major Italian airports


	   ROME (AP) _ Police reinforced security at Italy's two main
international airports Friday as well as at other places considered
possible targets in case of retaliation by terrorists for the U.S.
bombings in Afghanistan and Sudan.
	   ``The measures were taken following ministerial instructions and
from police headquarters in Rome,'' said Francesco Girasoli, head
of police at Rome's Leonardo da Vinci airport. ``The controls have
been stepped up as in maximum-alert periods.''
	   Girasoli said deployment of police at the airport was stepped
up, and the Italian news agency ANSA reported that private security
companies that assist the U.S. airlines TWA and Delta with security
and check-in had also stepped up staffing.
	   In Milan's Malpensa airport, served by several U.S. airlines,
security was also increased, ANSA said.
	   Guard posts and well as passing police patrols were also
reported reinforced in Milan at the U.S. Consulate, offices of U.S.
airlines and American schools.
	   (fd)

results.content:
1998-07-02 
 Nigeria Beefs Up Security for Airports 


LAGOS, July 2 (Xinhua) -- All aircraft entering and leaving
Nigerian airports are now to be accompanied by armed security
escort to the holding point of take-off to forestall cases of
aircraft robbery.


The new security measure came on the heels of the recent
robbery of an Air Afrique aircraft and vandalization and theft of
components of navigation and landing approach equipment at the
Lagos international airport.


The Federal Airports Authority of Nigeria (FAAN) in a
statement Wednesday also announced that all unauthorized persons
found on the runway would be shot at sight, warning that security
personnel had been given orders to that effect.


FAAN said bushes and other obstacles on the runway were being
cleared for easy view of all equipment, while maintenance and
security staff had been equipped with radios and walkie-talkies
to monitor all equipment.


It also pledged to improve all lightening systems for adequate
security.


Some 10 years ago, a shoot-on-sight order was given to
security personnel at Lagos international airport following
incessant theft on the runway, the semi-government newspaper
Daily Times reported Thursday.


Two weeks ago, some security personnel were arrested in
connection with the vandalization of the instrument landing aids
worth more than six million U.S. Dollars.


Last week, robbers attacked an Air Afrique Beoing 727
aircraft, breaking into the luggage compartment, when the plane
was waiting in darkness for clearance to take off.

results.content:
1999-03-11 05:59:12 
 international 
 78 U.S. Airports to Undergo Security Reviews 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- Nearly 80 of the nation's largest airports  
will undergo an extensive security review by the Federal Aviation 
Administration, as it cracks down on reported lapses in controlled 
access to secured areas. 


	The FAA launched the six-week review after auditors in a survey  
of five airports found inadequate safeguards for keeping 
unauthorized personnel out of secured areas. Once federal officials 
have scrutinized security measures at the nation's 78 largest 
commercial airports, they will then look into smaller commercial 
airports. 


	``We decided it would be worthwhile to look at the issue of  
access to non-public areas of airports on a broader scale,'' FAA 
spokesman Eliot Brenner said Wednesday. The agency will also 
determine whether it needs to do ``red team testing'' -- such as 
sending undercover agents to try to penetrate security -- to ensure 
that identified problem areas have been addressed after the review. 


	The FAA's security crackdown follows tests by federal agents at  
five major airports. Testifying before the House Appropriations 
Committee's panel on transportation and related agencies, the 
auditors reported Wednesday they were able to bypass secured areas 
and even board the planes. 


	``In a high percentage of tests involving airport access  
controls, our successful penetration of secure areas almost always 
resulted in our boarding an aircraft,'' said Alexis Stefani, the 
Transportation Department's deputy assistant inspector general for 
aviation. 


	Stefani told lawmakers many of the problems found in a similar  
audit in 1993 still exist. For example, Stefani said, undercover 
personnel could enter through emergency exits and penetrate air 
cargo facilities by following airport personnel through access 
control points. 


	The majority of individuals encountered by the agents failed to  
challenge them for unauthorized access and in some cases, airport 
law enforcement officials failed to respond to emergency door 
alarms. At two airports, undercover auditors bypassed passenger 
screening checkpoints and entered the concourse. 


	Stefani attributed the ``human element'' as the primary weakness  
in keeping unauthorized personnel out of secured areas. 


	The FAA's inspection and testing of airport security also needs  
strengthening, Stefani said. 


	The agency sets guidelines and establishes procedures for  
security, while airports are responsible for controlling access to 
secured areas within the facility. Airlines oversee passengers and 
cargo. Airports and airlines together have historically been 
responsible for maintaining security equipment and systems. 


	In a letter sent to airports, Retired Adm. Cathal Flynn, the  
FAA's associate administrator for civil aviation security, said 
unauthorized personnel sneaking past controlled access represents a 
serious security breech. 


	``Allowing intruders to piggyback through access doors, not  
challenging intruders on the ramp, and intruders being able to get 
aboard aircraft, combine to make a significant vulnerability,'' 
Flynn wrote. 


	He suggested that ``redundant measures, such as guarding the  
individual aircraft,'' could be required if the problems persist. 


	The Dallas Morning News reported in its Wednesday editions that  
federal agents were able to get through security doors 46 times at 
four major airports, walk around on the tarmac and board 51 
airplanes unchallenged.

results.content:
FEDERAL AUTHORITIES CALL FOR BOOSTING SECURITY MEASURES AT
AIRPORTS 



   Federal authorities, increasingly concerned about the
possibility of a holiday terrorist attack, took additional steps
Tuesday to safeguard Americans by adding inspectors to monitor
security operations at airports.


   The Federal Aviation Administration said that travelers should
expect stricter enforcement of parking regulations, and that it
would make more use of devices to check airline passengers for
small traces of explosives. Additional bomb-sniffing dogs and
uniformed police also will patrol airports as the new year
approaches.


   The concerns come after last week's arrest of an Algerian who
brought bomb-making material into Washington state from Canada.


   Still, federal authorities say they have no evidence about
specific terrorist attacks on U.S. soil.


   ``We don't want to overly concern people,'' said Jeff Lanza,
spokesman for the FBI's Kansas City office. ``The chances of
anything happening are very slim, but we want to take every
precaution.''


   Kansas City International Airport officials have not planned any
additional security measures for the new year. KCI spokeswoman Tara
Smith said Tuesday that the existing security measures at KCI
already are very strict.


   ``We consider this an advisory rather than a mandate,'' Smith
said of the FAA's action.


   Airport police do not allow people to leave unattended vehicles
at the curb. Numerous security cameras are mounted throughout KCI,
and airport police have two dogs that can sniff suspicious-looking
bags.


   As in past years, KCI officials advise holiday travelers not to
gift wrap items to carry aboard planes and to check in at least an
hour before takeoff on domestic flights and two hours before
international flights.


   Authorities in Kansas City are allocating more manpower as the
New Year approaches and are working with planners of large-scale
events.


   As many as 5,000 partiers will celebrate in Union Station,
perhaps the area's biggest bash. Revelers will pay up to $500 for a
black-tie dinner, live music and fireworks. Up to 10,000 will
celebrate in tents outside.


   Event organizer Stacy McCullough said police have worked with
organizers from the start, even sitting in on planning meetings.
Police and private security will work at the event.


   Partiers will pass through metal detectors as added protection.


   ``We hope people keep things in perspective,'' McCullough said.
``We're very comfortable with what we're doing. We're doing
everything on our end to ensure a safe environment.''


   The FBI's local office will set up a command post to monitor
criminal activities over New Year's and will contribute agents to a
Federal Emergency Management Agency command post that opens this
week.


   The FBI, like many businesses, has limited out-of-town travel
among agents so they will be available.


   The Kansas City Police Department plans to call most of its
officers in to work 12-hour shifts throughout the holiday. They
will be deployed throughout the city, not necessarily at
high-profile events.


   For the past two years, field supervisors have randomly
participated in responding to mock critical incidents from Y2K
problems to natural disasters, said Officer Steve Young, a police
spokesman.


   Supervisors are asked how they would utilize resources such as
the Missouri Highway Patrol, MAST or the city's public works
department. Police also have met regularly with city and health
officials, Young said.


   ``All we are doing is everything we can to be ready for
anything,'' Young said.

results.content:
1999-12-18 
 Fire Ravages Panama City International Airport 


PANAMA CITY, December 17 (Xinhua) -- The Tocumen International
Airport of the Panamanian capital caught fire this morning, Victor
de la Hoz, Civil Aeronautics Direction (DAC) spokesman said on
Friday.


The spokesman said that there is information about four injured
people, although it was not said whether they are airport
employees or fire department personnel who are trying to stop the
fire.


De la Hoz said that the fire may have started with a strong
detonation in the ground floor of the airport building, where the
DAC warehouses are located.


The first versions given by the Panamanian authorities also say
that the fire could have started in a nearby power plant, located
in the airport ground floor.


The Panamanian official said that the magnitude of the fire had
caused air operations to be suspended, and measures of extreme
security had been implemented to protect the users.


The airport authorities said that the causes of the fires are
being investigated.

FAA also recommended certification of airport security workers and better training of all airline a
results.content:
1996-12-13 
 Aviation Panel Recommends New Airport Security Measures 


WASHINGTON, December 12 (Xinhua) -- A U.S. Federal Aviation
Administration (FAA) advisory panel today proposed an overhaul of
the nation's airport security by new measures to prevent terrorist
activities.


The measures, ranging from new passenger and baggage screening
to tighter cargo security, will cost 9.9 billion U.S. dollars over
the next 10 years.


The panel said its recommendations were focused on "terrorist
attacks related to weapons and explosives introduced into the
civil aviation system".


The panel suggested greater use of high-tech equipment, sniffer
dogs and trained security managers to detect explosive devices and
material in cargo, mail, baggage, carry-ons and on passengers at
U.S. airports.


FAA also recommended certification of airport security workers
and better training of all airline and airport personnel.


Other major measures the panel proposed include: matching all
baggage to passengers and screening any bags from passengers under
surveillance by hand, X-ray, or explosive detection equipment;
testing reinforced cargo containers; and screening suspect
passengers.

results.content:
Report: Israel increases security at airports following threats


	   LOD, Israel (AP) _ Israel is tightening security at its airports
in response to threats by Islamic militants to attack Israeli and
U.S. targets, including airlines, Israel radio said Monday.
	   Israel Airport Authority officials were in a meeting Monday
morning and not immediately available for comment.
	   Threats against U.S. and Israeli targets emerged after last
week's U.S. air strikes in Sudan and Afghanistan that were aimed at
Osama bin Laden, a Saudi millionaire and Islamic militant linked to
the bombings of two U.S. embassies in East Africa this month.
	   On Sunday, a leading Muslim activist close to bin Laden said
Islamic militants are preparing to retaliate for the air strikes by
targeting U.S. and Israeli strategic sites and airliners.
	   Israel radio said security was being tightened at Ben Gurion
International Airport near Tel Aviv and at airfields in Eilat and
Tel Aviv. At Ben Gurion, cars entering the airport were being
checked more closely and some delays were being reported in getting
into the airport, the radio said.
	   In a related development, the Haaretz daily said that metal
detectors at Ben Gurion do not pick up certain items that contain
metal, including kitchen knives and big key chains.
	   Haaretz tested the five metal detectors in the departure hall
twice and found that the equipment did not pick up on metal items
weighing about 350 grams, or a little over half a pound.
	   Security measures at Ben Gurion are among the most stringent
worldwide. Motorists are stopped at checkpoints at the airport
entrances, with some passengers _ generally Palestinians _ being
questioned there and having their luggage checked.
	   In the departure lounge, tourists, Palestinians and Israeli Arab
citizens are questioned at length, while Jewish Israelis usually
undergo only a perfunctory check.

results.content:
1996-03-27 17:54 
 Roundup: Greece Rejects US Allegations on Airport  Safety Issue (by Chen Dechang) 


ATHENS, March 27 (Xinhua) -- Greece has repeatedly rejected
American allegations that the security conditions at the Athens
International Airport were "among the three worst in the world,"
insisting the reality is just the opposite.


Refuting the American allegations, Greek government spokesman
Dimitris Reppas said "the security conditions at the airport are
good."


In a report published last Thursday, the U.S. Transportation
Department singled out the airports of Athens, Lagos (Nigeria) and
Bogota (Colombia) as not being up to par with international
security standards.


The U.S. Transportation Department later ordered all air
tickets from the U.S. to Greece must bear a sticker cautioning
travelers that the Athens airport "does not maintain and carry
out effective airport security measures."


Greek Development Minister Vasso Papandreou met with U.S.
Ambassador to Athens Thomas Niles today to express Greece's
displeasure over the warning "which does not reflect reality."


Papandreou reiterated that security at the Athens airport was
quite adequate, underling that major airline companies such as
Lufthansa and Swissair had stopped using private security firms
because of satisfaction with the services provided by the Greek
authorities.


Greek hoteliers and transport officials are furious at the U.S.
move, fearing the Greek tourism industry would be adversely
affected.


The Greek concern has been raised by estimates that an
increased number of Americans were planning to vacation in Greece
this year, bringing the number of visitors to above last year's
figure of over 300,000. A U.S. travel advisory in 1985 produced
devastating results: the number of visits that year dropped to
just 100,000 from 600,000 in 1984.


Greek Prime Minister Costas Simitis reportedly intervened to
stop the U.S. from issuing a travel advisory but Greek tour
operators say that even with the less formal warning stickers,
years of effort to regain trust in the U.S. market could be
wasted.


Other senior officials, including the country's Transport
Minister Haris Kastanidis, have also lashed out at the American
action. Speaking to the press earlier, Kastanidis said Washington
was using the warning as a means of political pressure on Athens,
and warned that Athens considered the issue of warning stickers
"a hostile act against our country."


"The Americans should first take a look at their own statistics
of the terrorist actions taking place at their airports and then
concern themselves with the Athens airport, which is among the
safest in the world," Michalis Perros, head of Greece's Civil
Aviation Union was quoted as saying by local press reports today.


It was reported that a group of U.S. travel experts are due to
come to Athens to inspect the airport but the Greek Transport
Ministry was considering whether they would permit the visit.


Government spokesman Reppas said Prime Minister Simitis had
requested the lifting of the U.S. warning during a meeting with
Ambassador Niles today and Niles promised that every effort would
be made to "resolve the issue within 30 days."

results.content:
1996-07-20 
 Greece Dismisses Linkage With Plane Crash 


ATHENS, July 19 (Xinhua) -- The Greek Civil Aviation Authority
today angrily dismissed press speculation attempting to implicate
Athens airport security in explosion of a TWA airliner Wednesday
after take-off from New York.


"We cannot understand this organized attack on Athens airport,"
Dionysis Kalofonos, director of administration at Greece's Civil
Administration Service, said. "This foreign press speculation is
an attempt to mislead public opinion".


"We have always worked with U.S. agencies to protect U.S.
citizens abroad," he added.


TWA has an agreement with Athens airport to conduct its own
security checks on passengers and luggage, on all flights to the
U.S., he said.


"Security measures at Athens airport are the best in the world
because we did not only go through a three-fold check, it went
through a five-fold check with TWA," he added.


Apart from stringent Greek checks, TWA's own equipment scans
passengers and their luggage at the check-in counter. An
additional TWA check on passengers and hand luggage is conducted
before the aircraft is boarded.


TWA aircraft are parked at a site chosen by TWA's security and
guarded by Greek anti-terrorist police, a regular police patrol
and TWA security, who are the only ones permitted aboard the plane
while it is on the tarmac and have responsibility for supervising
cleaning and other tarmac services.


He said the Greek authorities were satisfied that security on
the flight was in accordance with the regulations and that there
was no reason to conduct any further inquiry at this end.


The plane came down, he added, after the Athens-New York flight
had terminated.


"As far as we, and international law, are concerned, our duty
ends when a flight leaves Athens," he said. The moment the plane
was assigned to a new flight, the responsibility for it rested
with Kennedy airport, he added.


All 229 passengers and crew of the Boeing 747 died in the
crash, the cause of which is as yet unknown.

results.content:
1996-08-02 
 Security at Pakistan Airports Tightened 


ISLAMABAD, August 1 (Xinhua) -- Following the bomb blast at the
airport of Punjab provincial capital of Lahore, security at all
airports in Pakistan was further tightened.


The measures taken and put into implementation were explained
in detail by the chief of Airport Security Force (ASF), Rasheed
Malik, at a briefing today in the southern port city of Karachi,
according to local reports.


He said the ASF will be responsible for airport security, from
the "first entry" to the "air side".


According to the new rules, people carrying the baggage of
others will not be allowed to enter the airport. All screening
machines of the ASF will be kept operating during peak hours.


The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) is being asked to remove
congestion from verandahs of the airport while the ASF will cover
the security of verandahs and parking area.


Events at the parking area will be filmed and night patrolling
on foot and mobile will be increased.


The ASF is issuing new stickers for car parking to employees of
various agencies working at the airport.


About Airport Entry Passes, which allow holders to enter
airport freely, the ASF chief pointed out that their misuse will
be dealt with a heavy hand and the misusers will not be issued
passes again.


He said the ASF hopes to collect 150 million (4.29 million US
dollars) as airport security charges every year, which will be
spent on acquiring screening machines for the ASF and to further
modernize the security arrangements.


The ASF Chief said the security measures being taken may cause
some discomfort to passengers and all other concerned but they all
will have to bear it under the prevailing conditions.

results.content:
SENATE PASSES BILL THAT INCLUDES MONEY FOR KANSAS CITY
INTERNATIONAL 



   WASHINGTON _ A measure that passed the Senate on Wednesday calls
for $11.6 million in airport improvements at Kansas City
International Airport and may open the way for more nonstop flights
from KCI to Washington's Reagan National Airport.


   The conference report releases federal funds to pay for most of
the cost of resurfacing concrete aprons around the terminals and
upgrading security in doorways leading from the terminals to
airplanes and to ground areas.


   ``This is new money for us,'' said Russell Widmar, aviation
director for the city of Kansas City, which runs KCI. ``We're
excited about it.''


   The KCI projects are part of $40 billion in Federal Aviation
Administration spending nationwide in the next three years that the
Senate and House have debated for months. It is expected to win
House approval next week, said Steve Hilton, spokesman for Sen.
John Ashcroft, a Missouri Republican.


   Widmar said some of the federal money would pay for the final
segments of a seven-phase program to replace concrete aprons built
in the early 1970s. And $4.6 million would pay for security,
including conversion of secured doorways to card rather than key
systems.


   The bill also has about $38 million for improvements at eight
other Missouri airports, including $26.54 million for Lambert-St.
Louis International Airport.


   ``Missouri airports will be able to move ahead with ambitious
modernization programs,'' Ashcroft said.


   Ashcroft was sponsor of an amendment to the bill that would open
24 more slots at Reagan National Airport, which has tight capacity
restrictions. Half of those slots would be for flights from cities
beyond the current limit of 1,250 miles.


   The other 12 slots would be available for flights from cities
such as Kansas City that are within 1,250 miles. Two carriers _
Midwest Express and Vanguard Airlines _ have expressed interest in
adding nonstop service to Reagan National. Only USAir now offers
such service.


   ``Those will be very hard slots to get,'' Widmar said. ``They
will be competitive among all the cities.''


   A spokeswoman for Vanguard Airlines in Kansas City said it was
too early to say whether the airline would propose serving Reagan
National. Gate availability and landing fees at KCI will be among
factors in the decision, she said.


   A public affairs official of Midwest Express did not return a
call for comment on Wednesday, but Widmar said he had heard that
the Milwaukee-based airline would also be interested in serving
Reagan National.

results.content:
OFFICIALS DOWNPLAY DANGERS 



   SEATTLE _ ``Chester the Molester,'' as the cops called him,
accosted six women last year in the Los Angeles International
Airport garage.


   The seventh time, police were ready.


   An officer monitoring cameras at each entrance saw the suspect
drive up, and ``Chester'' is now behind bars.


   Los Angeles is just one of the airports around the nation using
cameras and heavy patrols to fight crime in airport lots _ measures
that are lacking at Sea-Tac.


   The Post-Intelligencer found that the Sea-Tac garage is patroled
an average of less than once a day, that the few cameras in the lot
are linked to maintenance rather than security, and that a
half-dozen of the port's own police officers had warned of security
gaps long ago.


   Sea-Tac's police force also is stretched more thinly than at
those airports, the P-I found.


   Port Commissioner Paige Miller Tuesday said she has asked port
staff to review how Sea-Tac differs from other airports in patrols
and surveillance.


   ``It is reasonable,'' she said, ``to ask what other airports are
doing.''


   But like other three other port commissioners interviewed, she
stressed that the garage has been the scene of very few violent
crimes. Miller said it's important to note that most crimes at the
garage have been crimes of property, like car prowls, and not rapes
or assaults.


   And that leaves little reason for boosting garage staffing, said
Aviation director Gina Marie Lindsey.


   ``History doesn't seem to warrant throwing a lot of folks and
technology at the garage,'' Lindsey said.


   A woman shot two years ago in the huge Sea-Tac garage is suing
the port for negligence, but port officials say no security
measures could prevent that kind of sudden attack.


   But interviews with police at other airports around the country
show that they devote special resources to keeping their garages as
safe as possible.


   Police at Washington's Dulles aim cameras to cover every blind
spot at the lot. At Boston's Logan, troopers sometimes stake out
BMWs and other fancy cars on the chance thieves will target them.


   San Francisco's lots are watched by private security guards on
every floor, while L.A. officers sometimes use military
night-vision goggles to watch the sprawling airport lots.


   ``We're kind of proud of what we've been able to do,'' said L.A.
airport police Capt. John Bangs. ``Every garage gets patrolled at
least a couple of times every shift.''


   Documents filed with the lawsuit indicate that the Sea-Tac
garage is not routinely patrolled, though officers from other beats
sometimes make checks there.


   Officials at other airports _ as well as nationally recognized
experts on parking _ say garages require special vigilence. They're
where people leave one of their most valuable and treasure-filled
possessions, and any theft that's interrupted has the potential to
turn violent.


   ``Security should be at the top of the mind of anyone who's
offering parking to the public,'' said Brad Parrish, president of
V.P. Services, a consulting firm for parking operators.


   Another Seattle parking consultant, Greg Jacobson, said visible
security is simply good business, making people more more likely to
return.


   ``My feeling,'' he said, ``is spend the money.''


   Many garage planners at malls and other facilities follow that
advice.


   Below downtown Seattle, the 1,200-stall Pacific Place garage is
literally as bright as day thanks to white metal-halide bulbs
cranking out an average of 7.5 foot candles of illumination.


   That's about 14 times the brightness given off by the amber
lamps at the Sea-Tac garage, where Jacobson said the lighting level
is about one-half a foot candle _ roughly the visibility of the
desert in a full moon.


   ``What was really key for us,'' said Pacific Place spokeswoman
Jane Lewis, ``is that from the drawing board on up, the security
and comfort of the user were important.''


   Pacific Place designers also enhanced security by painting the
walls a reflective white and by removing s

results.content:
1997-08-25 
 India to Provide Better Airport Facilities 


NEW DELHI, August 25 (XINHUA) -- India's Civil Aviation
Ministry is planning to take measures to make airports
passenger-friendly, the ministry sources said here today.


The main focus of the plan is on reducing the time taken for
check in, baggage handling, security, Customs clearance and
immigration procedures.


The ultimate aim in chalking out plans for better passenger
facilitation is to clear incoming international passengers within
45 minutes of arrival.


In the case of outbound passengers, the all formalities
including check in should be completed within 60 minutes.


Efforts will also be made to considerably cut down the time
spent by domestic passengers at various airports.


All future investments in airports, whether it is a new
project, modernization or expansion, will focus primarily on
passenger facilitation.


All efforts will also be made for greater private sector
participation, in order to ensure higher investment flow and
improved efficiency of services.


Foreign investment, even to the extent of 100 percent, will be
allowed in airport projects, the same sources said.

results.content:
1999-03-11 02:13:45 
 washington 
 FAA To Check Security at Airports 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- Nearly 80 of the nation's largest airports  
will undergo an extensive security review by the Federal Aviation 
Administration, as it cracks down on reported lapses in controlled 
access to secured areas. 


	The FAA launched the six-week review after auditors in a survey  
of five airports found inadequate safeguards for keeping 
unauthorized personnel out of secured areas. Once federal officials 
have scrutinized security measures at the nation's 78 largest 
commercial airports, they will then look into smaller commercial 
airports. 


	``We decided it would be worthwhile to look at the issue of  
access to non-public areas of airports on a broader scale,'' FAA 
spokesman Eliot Brenner said Wednesday. The agency will also 
determine whether it needs to do ``red team testing'' -- such as 
sending undercover agents to try to penetrate security -- to ensure 
that identified problem areas have been addressed after the review. 


	The FAA's security crackdown follows tests by federal agents at  
five major airports. Testifying before the House Appropriations 
Committee's panel on transportation and related agencies, the 
auditors reported Wednesday they were able to bypass secured areas 
and even board the planes. 


	``In a high percentage of tests involving airport access  
controls, our successful penetration of secure areas almost always 
resulted in our boarding an aircraft,'' said Alexis Stefani, the 
Transportation Department's deputy assistant inspector general for 
aviation. 


	Stefani told lawmakers many of the problems found in a similar  
audit in 1993 still exist. For example, Stefani said, undercover 
personnel could enter through emergency exits and penetrate air 
cargo facilities by following airport personnel through access 
control points. 


	The majority of individuals encountered by the agents failed to  
challenge them for unauthorized access and in some cases, airport 
law enforcement officials failed to respond to emergency door 
alarms. At two airports, undercover auditors bypassed passenger 
screening checkpoints and entered the concourse. 


	Stefani attributed the ``human element'' as the primary weakness  
in keeping unauthorized personnel out of secured areas. 


	The FAA's inspection and testing of airport security also needs  
strengthening, Stefani said. 


	The agency sets guidelines and establishes procedures for  
security, while airports are responsible for controlling access to 
secured areas within the facility. Airlines oversee passengers and 
cargo. Airports and airlines together have historically been 
responsible for maintaining security equipment and systems. 


	In a letter sent to airports, Retired Adm. Cathal Flynn, the  
FAA's associate administrator for civil aviation security, said 
unauthorized personnel sneaking past controlled access represents a 
serious security breech. 


	``Allowing intruders to piggyback through access doors, not  
challenging intruders on the ramp, and intruders being able to get 
aboard aircraft, combine to make a significant vulnerability,'' 
Flynn wrote. 


	He suggested that ``redundant measures, such as guarding the  
individual aircraft,'' could be required if the problems persist. 


	The Dallas Morning News reported in its Wednesday editions that  
federal agents were able to get through security doors 46 times at 
four major airports, walk around on the tarmac and board 51 
airplanes unchallenged.

results.content:
&HT;   



   WASHINGTON _ The morning after surprise U.S. military air
strikes against terrorist operations in Sudan and Afghanistan, many
Americans woke to their own ``terrorist warnings'' about their
daily train ride to work or their weekend sightseeing destinations.


   From coast to coast, in airports, train stations and even
popular tourist attractions, security was heightened on Friday by
officials fearing a possible -- no matter how remote -- terrorist
retaliation for the U.S. air strikes.


   Here, in the nation's capitol, the local transit authority
increased police patrols throughout the busy regional rail system
and said it is taking ``a number of other measures'' to ensure the
safety of its passengers.


   During train rides, thousands of riders heard announcements
urging them to adhere to safety precautions such as using emergency
intercoms on the trains and at the stations to report anything
``unusual.''


   ``We are reminding passengers who see any suspicious persons,
packages or activities to contact Metro personnel immediately,''
said Metro System Police Chief Barry McDevitt.


   Despite the warnings, however, most passengers didn't seem
worried.


   ``It's the same-old, same-old,'' said Linda Hicks, a native
Washingtonian. ``I don't really feel any different.''


   Hicks, 42, said she knows the government will protect her
because terrorists have never attacked D.C. in her lifetime.


   ``I've never known any building to be blown up in D.C.,'' she
said.


   Metro System police and other personnel, who were advised to be
extra vigilant in light of the international developments, also
said Friday was business-as-usual.


   ``People are very calm. They haven't asked any questions,'' said
officer Tito Aguilar.


   The safety precautions are a reaction to Thursday's surprise
attacks in which U.S. cruise missiles destroyed a suspected
chemical weapons factory in Sudan, and hit a terrorist training
camp in a remote, hilly region of Afghanistan.


   Many military experts say a swift retaliatory strike against the
U.S. is unlikely, especially within U.S. borders.


   Nonetheless, at Ellis Island, the Statue of Liberty and all
other federal park sites in New York City, security was increased
immediately.


   At Ellis Island, Lt. Don Roofener said tourists Friday were not
asking about security. ``They don't seem to be afraid,'' he said.


   Also in New York, the police department went on a
heightened-alert status, just moments after President Clinton
announced the bombings. Police Commissioner Howard Safir referred
to it as ``Condition Bravo,'' which entails beefed up patrols at
consulates, religious institutions and other sensitive locations.


   While Federal Aviation Administration said Friday's ``heightened
state of emergency'' has become standard procedure over the past
three years, many of the nation's largest airports stepped up
security noticeably.


   On the West Coast, at Los Angeles International Airport,
security was increased and police said they would monitor the local
situation for any potential problems. Airport officials also
advised passengers to expect some delays due to closer screening of
baggage and other materials.


   At Chicago's O'Hare International Airport, bomb-sniffing dogs
and police officers were on increased patrols. Airport security
officials at Atlanta's Hartsfield International Airport warned
passengers to arrive early for their flights and not to leave their
cars unattended or they would be towed.


   (EDs: Story can end here. Optional add follows.)


   In Washington, U.S. Park Police ``increased patrols and
heightened security'' at all national monuments including the
Washington, Lincoln and Jefferson memorials and the national Mall.


   ``It's a very political area and we have to react to what's
happening,'' said U.S. Park Police Capt. Valerie Fernandes.


   The last time Fernandes recalls this type of heightened security
was during Operation: Desert Storm. She said the precautions are
not an indication that a strike is expected but that ``it's better

1999-10-31 08:00:13 
 usa 
 FAA Got Plane Bomb Alert Last Month 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- A month ago, the Federal Aviation  
Administration issued an alert to airline and airport security 
personnel after agencies received an unconfirmed warning that a 
bomb would ``soon be used'' on a flight departing from Los Angeles 
or Kennedy airport in New York. 


	Officials said they had no reason to believe the disappearance  
of an EgyptAir flight on Sunday was caused by sabotage. 
Investigators were attempting to determine the fate of Flight 990 
after takeoff from Kennedy International Airport. The flight 
originated Saturday in Los Angeles. 


	Many aviation warnings are investigated each month by federal  
agencies and the Sept. 24 alert said: ``At this time, FAA has no 
information to corroborate the statements in the letter and assess 
them as lacking credibility.'' 


	Asked about the alert, David Leavy, spokesman for National  
Security Council, told The Associated Press, ``I don't want to 
speculate on this until we have information.'' 


	A U.S. intelligence official said at midmorning Sunday that  
agencies were pursuing the possibility of sabotage, but, ``There's 
nothing to immediately point toward that.'' Another official said 
there had been no recent threat that seemed relevant to the 
EgyptAir disappearance. 


	A third official said there had been no immediate credit claims  
made to the U.S. government. 


	The official said law enforcement agencies are reviewing past  
tips and phone traffic to see if there was a lead that was passed 
over before and might be relevant after the plane disappeared. 


	``We don't want to sit around a week and then find out this was  
a crime and start investigating,'' the official said. 


	In a Sept. 24 ``information circular,'' a copy of which was  
obtained by the AP, the FAA said several U.S. agencies received a 
warning by letter in August ``that a bomb or explosive device with 
`spiral expansion' would soon be used on a flight departing from 
either Los Angeles airport or New York's JFK airport.'' 


	The circular said the informant ``identified himself as Luciano  
Porcari,'' and noted that ``an individual with this same name 
hijacked an Iberian Boeing 727 during a flight from Barcelona to 
Palma de Mallorca, Spain, on March 14, 1977,'' before being 
overpowered and arrested. 


	The alert said the writer said ``three of these devices were  
smuggled into the United States between 1992 and 1993, and that the 
devices cannot be detected on a metal detector because of the PVC 
(plastic) composition.'' 


	The alert was in effect until Oct. 30. EgyptAir Flight 990  
departed Los Angeles on Saturday, Oct. 30, and stopped at John F. 
Kennedy International Airport, bound for Cairo. The plane took off 
from JFK at 1:19 a.m. Sunday en route to Cairo and disappeared from 
radar screens about 40 minutes later. 


	At a news conference in Cairo, the head of EgyptAir, Mohammed  
Fahim Rayan, said he had no information of any direct threat 
against his airline. 


	Last month, the FAA offered no comment on its alert.  


	``The FAA often sends out information on threats to ensure that  
airlines can properly implement security measures,'' agency 
spokeswoman Rebecca Trexler said at the time. 


	``We do want to assure the public that the FAA works with law  
enforcement and intelligence agencies of the United States and 
other countries and we closely evaluate all threats and take 
appropriate security measures as warranted,'' Trexler added. 


	The FAA circular said a Luciano Porcari was sentenced to 10  
years in prison on Jan. 25, 1979, but later escaped. In August 
1981, he threatened to hijack another aircraft unless he was paid 
$250,000. He was subsequently arrested in Italy and sentenced to 
nine years in prison on Jan. 27, 1982. The circular said he was 
released on Aug. 12, 1982, and his whereabouts were unknown. 


	In the warning received by letter ``to several U.S. government  
agencies,'' the informant ``claimed that between 1975 and 1983 
eight of the devices were

results.content:
2000-07-19 
 Lockerbie Defense Slams Frankfurt Airport Security 


CAMP ZEIST, Netherlands, July 19 (Xinhua) -- The defense team
at the Lockerbie trial on Wednesday pointed its finger at the lax
of security at the Frankfurt airport.


Jack Davidson, one of the defense counsels, said a United
States Federal Aviation Authority inspection had criticised Pan Am
security at the airport just months after the December 1988 mid-
air bombing that killed 259 people on board Pan Am Flight 103 and
11 others on the ground.


"It is my opinion that U.S. citizens are at risk when they fly
out of this airport," said Davidson quoting a Federal Aviation
Authority report dated May 23, 1989.


The defense counsel said that undercover Federal Aviation
Authority inspectors had been able to rummage unchallenged through
Pan Am luggage containers at the Frankfurt airport in January 1989
and roam around parked aircraft and unguarded luggage with no
visible identity badges on them.


"It is apparent that drastic measures must be taken to ensure
that Pan Am conforms to even minimum requirements," said Davidson
quoting the same report.


The prosecution accused Abdel Basset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin
Khalifa Fahima of working as Libyan Arab Airlines employees at
Malta's Luqa airport to put a bomb on a plane heading for
Frankfurt. The bomb was then transferred onto the New York-bound
flight.


The prosecutors said that the two Libyans had put stolen Air
Malta luggage tags on the suitcase containing the bomb that caused
the mid-air explosion on December 21, 1988, over the Scottish town
of Lockerbie.


But the Libyans have entered a special defense by blaming
Palestinian terrorists in Frankfurt for the blast.


The prosecution will have to prove its case against the two
Libyans beyond reasonable doubt for the three Scottish judges to
give verdict. The two Libyans are charged with conspiracy of
murder, murder and breach of international aircraft safety laws.


If convicted, the two Libyans will have to serve their life
sentence in Scottish jail. If the case could not be proven, the
Libyans will have to be set free.


The Lockerbie trial went underway on May 3 this year after
almost 12 years of investigation and preparation and is now
expected to last up to a year.

results.content:
CITY HEIGHTENS SECURITY AMID FEARS OF TERRORIST REPRISAL



   NEW YORK _ Security was on high alert at all government
buildings, airports, bus and train terminals, bridges, tunnels and
other public places across the New York metropolitan area on
Thursday to guard against acts of terrorist retaliation for the
American air strikes against Iraq, federal and city officials said.


   Half a world away from the missiles raining down on Baghdad, New
York was hardly an armed camp, and the officials said it was not
being singled out among American cities for special security.
Similar precautions, they noted, were in effect at government and
transportation hubs across the country, particularly at airports.


   Moreover, while Defense Secretary William Cohen warned Thursday
of a generally increased threat of terrorist attacks in the United
States at any time, other federal officials said they had no fresh
intelligence reports that conveyed specific threats against New
York or any other city in America.


   But Mayor Rudolph Giuliani acknowledged at a City Hall news
conference that additional security measures were being taken. He
noted that since the bombing of two American embassies in Africa in
August, as well as the detention of suspects here, security in
general has been heightened, and he called the latest response a
``slight'' increase that many people might not notice.


   ``We had increased security throughout the city at significant
places,'' the mayor said, ``so the increase that's taken place now
shouldn't be felt by people. It's fairly subtle, but people should
understand we were already at a fairly high level of security.''


   Like the mayor, police officials declined to divulge details for
fear of compromising the measures. But they acknowledged that
hundreds of extra officers were being deployed at the United
Nations headquarters; at the World Trade Center, which was hit by a
terrorist bomb in 1993; and at government buildings and
transportation centers across the region.


   Heightened security procedures were evident at major
transportation centers. At Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark
International Airports, curb-side check-ins were canceled so that
baggage would not be left unattended. Similarly, vehicles standing
even briefly unattended near passenger terminals were being towed
away, officials said. And bomb-sniffing dogs were being used where
suspicions were raised.


   At the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels, at the George Washington and
Triboro Bridges, and at the other bridges and tunnels linking New
York, New Jersey, Long Island and the regional suburbs, extra
officers were on watch, and scores of vehicles, especially trucks
and vans, were being pulled over at random and checked, Port
Authority officials said.


   Bus and train terminals in New York and New Jersey also were
being watched by additional officers.


   Even some regular government employees known to security
officers were not allowed to pass freely. One official employed at
26 Federal Plaza, for example, said that officers of the Federal
Protective Service were opening and examining car trunks at random
at the garage entrance, even when they knew the driver, to guard
against any bomb planted surreptitiously.


   ``In general,'' one official said, ``in order to get into any
government building in New York, you have to show identification
and explain your reason for being there.''

results.content:
AIRPORTS LOOKING MORE AND MORE LIKE SHOPPING MALLS 



   It is not easy to squeeze into a dressing room with two pieces
of carry-on luggage and a laptop to try on a pair of jeans. And the
sight of three airline captains hovering over a table of pink
lingerie at Victoria's Secret still draws a second glance.


   But such scenes are quietly becoming as integral to air travel
as jet lag, weather delays and nondairy creamer. A number of
airports, somewhat surreal spaces where travelers were once content
to buy a few magazines and stare nervously at a clock, are starting
to look a lot like malls.


   In the last few years, dozens of national retailers have opened
airport shops, invading what has long been the domain of
newsstands, duty-free shops and the occasional live lobster stand
by establishing small outposts of the Gap, Victoria's Secret and
the like. At least one store, Altitunes, operates only in airports.
Such stores are joined by a full array of food chains, including
Starbucks and Legal Sea Foods.


   The strategy makes some sense. Many retailers have saturated the
nation's malls and downtowns, and are desperate for new places to
set up shop. And with both business and leisure travel at a
decade-long high, a lot of airports are scurrying to freshen up
their terminals.


   Running a business in an airport, though, can be a logistical
nightmare. In no mall in America, for instance, are food merchants
forced to take a dozen heads of lettuce through security. Many
workers balk at commuting to an airport. And customers often breeze
by shops in rushing to the gate.


   But for all the headaches, airport stores can be profitable:
Sales per square foot are often three or four times as high as
those for stores in other locations, even though prices are the
same as at malls. And ubiquitous delays coupled with the increased
security measures that force travelers to get to airports earlier
these days means these shoppers-in-motion often have more spare
time on their hands. Managers at Ronald Reagan Washington National
Airport say annual sales average $950 a square foot, more than
three times the business in an average mall store, where the figure
tends to be closer to $250 to $300.


   Airports from Heathrow, outside London, to Pittsburgh
International to La Guardia in New York to National have undergone
major renovations in recent years in which the addition of new
stores has played a key role. Others, like Chicago's O'Hare, are
following suit.


   While most American retailers have mall life down to a science,
though, they are finding that running a shop in an airport is
another story entirely.


   For one thing, airport rents are at least 20 percent higher,
usually paid out as a percentage of sales. And shoppers are likely
to spend only moments browsing.


   ``Airport retail is a tough business operationally,'' said
Judith Byrd, a principal with Unison Consulting Group, an airport
consultant in Chicago. ``The hours are longer, the rents are
higher. And you have to have an understanding of the market and
airline passenger flows.''


   Many retailing problems are unique to airports, like how to get
merchandise through customs and security and onto a selling floor
that is at most half the size of a company's average store.


   But others are similar to what every retailer faces, with some
twists. Location is usually the most important factor in a
retailer's success, but with airport shops, location has as much to
do with which airline a shop is parked next to as with what city
the airport is in and which department store is nearby.


   People who study airport retailing say the best-performing
strips are in hub airports, where lots of passengers are changing
planes and are thus forced to linger. Heavy international traffic
is a big plus. And it is always better to have the shops located
after the security point.


   ``Everybody is in a rush to get to the airport,'' said Michael
Bell, president of BAA PLC's American unit, which manages the shops
at Pittsburgh airport, one of the first American airports to entic

results.content:
1999-07-29 14:40:19 
 usa 
 Teen Stows Away on Flight to London 


	BOSTON (AP) -- A teen-ager who said he wanted to impress the  
Israeli intelligence agency sliced through a fence at Logan 
International Airport, settled into an empty seat aboard a British 
Airways jet and flew to London. 


	The airport, the airline and the boy, identified as 17-year-old  
Abraham Derman of Brookline, could be fined for the July 12 
escapade. 


	The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating, and the  
airline is considering asking the teen to come up with the $3,300 
it would have charged a paying passenger who made his journey. 


	``We're treating it extremely seriously,'' British Airways  
spokesman John Lampl said Thursday. ``The safety and security of 
our passengers is paramount.'' 


	Officials at the Massachusetts Port Authority, which operates  
the airport, said the breach of security was rare but extremely 
serious. They declined to comment further Thursday. 


	People familiar with the investigation said the teen's journey  
as a stowaway began when he scaled a 10- to 12-foot fence, cut the 
barbed wire at the top and dropped onto the tarmac area north of 
the main terminals. 


	They said Derman walked about a quarter-mile to the  
international terminal, where he climbed a metal staircase leading 
to a jetway, the tunnel joining the terminal with the waiting 
aircraft. 


	A jetway door, which is the airline's responsibility, is  
supposed to be locked. But the teen-ager apparently found it 
unlocked or open, and quickly boarded a Boeing 747 preparing for a 
trip to London. 


	Once on board Flight 214, Derman allegedly took a seat in the  
coach section, but had to move when the rightful ticket-holder 
arrived. He allegedly found an empty seat in the business section 
and settled in for the flight. 


	After landing at Heathrow Airport, the boy was confronted by  
officials after gaining access to a restricted area, according to 
the officials familiar with the case. 


	The next day, British Airways flew Derman back to Boston in  
coach class. He was detained and questioned -- though not arrested -- 
by state police. He told investigators he had thought the stunt 
would impress Israel's Mossad intelligence agency. 


	Derman, accompanied by his father, also gave investigators a  
step-by-step account of how he penetrated security, including in a 
walking tour in which he traced his route to the plane. 


	The Boston Globe reported Derman is 17, but that could not be  
verified. Calls made to a Brookline residence listed under the name 
Derman were not returned. 


	Part of the FAA investigation is likely to focus on the security  
measures taken by the airline. Airlines usually hand-count 
passengers and compare the number with the tickets collected at the 
gate.

results.content:
Israel increases security at airports following threats


	   LOD, Israel (AP) _ Israel is adding security personnel at its
international airport in response to threats by Islamic militants
to attack Israeli and U.S. targets, including airlines, officials
said Monday.
	   Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's senior adviser, David
Bar-Illan, said Israel would use all measures it deemed necessary
to fight terrorism.
	   Asked whether this included pre-emptive strikes, Bar-Illan told
The Associated Press: ``I don't want to be specific about anything
but obviously we are not ruling out anything.''
	   Threats against U.S. and Israeli targets emerged after last
week's U.S. air strikes in Sudan and Afghanistan that were aimed at
Osama bin Laden, a Saudi millionaire and Islamic militant linked to
the bombings of two U.S. embassies in East Africa this month.
	   On Sunday, a leading Muslim activist close to bin Laden said
Islamic militants are preparing to retaliate for the air strikes by
targeting U.S. and Israeli strategic sites and airliners.
	   A U.S. basketball team from the University of Connecticut, which
arrived Monday for a nine-day tour of friendly games, hired two
private security guards to accompany them in Israel.
	   ``The administration of the University of Connecticut demanded
bodyguards and we readily agreed,'' said the teams' tour operator
Nels Hawkinson. ``Had it not been for the bombings in Afghanistan
and Sudan we would not have seen the need,'' he said.
	   Pini Shis, 6th graf pvs

results.content:
AIRPORT SECURITY TO BE TIGHTENED 



   SEATTLE _ Sea-Tac Airport managers promised Tuesday to add
police patrols, improve lighting, upgrade emergency call boxes and
take other steps to heighten security in the huge parking garage.


   The measures come after a Post-Intelligencer series on security
gaps in the garage, and the port's payment of $2.6 million to
settle a shooting victim's lawsuit.


   ``There's been some fear recently, and we want to have that
alleviated,'' Gina Marie Lindsey, aviation director, told Port of
Seattle commissioners Tuesday.


   The P-I reported in March that unlike the lots at most other
major airports surveyed, the Sea-Tac garage had infrequent police
patrols, no emergency panic buttons and lighting that fell far
short of current industry standards.


   Measures unveiled Tuesday would correct some of those
conditions, but Lindsey said the 10,000-stall garage already was
relatively safe.


   The upgrades, she said, are intended not only to make travelers
feel more secure, but to smooth their way through an increasingly
crowded facility.


   Still, she said public fear generated by the P-I series had
helped initiate or speed up several changes:


   (BBOX)Stepping up patrols so there is one police officer
somewhere in the eight-story garage at least half of each day.


   Previously, the garage was not patrolled at all many days,
except on a spot basis.


   (BBOX)Circulating electric carts topped by flashing lights
carrying customer-service agents. They will be able to direct lost
motorists and lend a uniformed presence in the garage.


   (BBOX)Offering Block Watch-style training in coming weeks to
airport and airline workers to help them spot security problems and
know how to respond.


   (BBOX)Modifying emergency telephones in the next three weeks to
transmit to dispatchers the caller's exact location.


   (BBOX)Replacing the lamps in older sections of the garage and
redesigning the garage's lighting to eliminate severe contrast
between dark and light areas.


   Only the lighting project was given a specific pricetag: $4.5
million, an allocation that will require approval by the port
commission in about two months.


   Studies on how to improve the lighting had long been under way,
Lindsey said, but the project probably would not have been launched
for another year without the recent publicity.


   The added police patrols in the garage began about four weeks
ago, she said. The other safety measures will be launched as soon
as possible.


   In addition, she said, port officials also are studying
longer-term security changes such as installing a network of
security cameras.


   The only cameras now in the garage are used to check maintenance
conditions around the elevators. In the coming weeks, Lindsey said,
the facilities personnel who monitor those cameras will be trained
to spot and report security problems, as well.


   Lindsey presented the security improvements as part of a larger
package of ``customer-service'' upgrades.


   The eight-story airport garage _ which Sea-Tac officials believe
to be the largest single parking structure in the nation _ is
bulging at the seams. It handled four million cars last year, which
carried many of the 25.8 million people who flew through Sea-Tac.
Last year, the structure generated a $34 million profit.


   The garage regularly fills up twice a week _ typically midday
Wednesdays and Thursdays _ and the congestion is only getting
worse.


   A hotline (206-433-5308) alerts motorists to sold-out
situations, alternative parking locales, and other conditions. The
airport's website (www.portseattle.org/seatac) will be upgraded by
late May to do the same.


   Airport officials also promise to have in place by October a
speedy pay-on-the-way-to-your-car exit system, and to add 3,000 new
parking stalls by July 2000.


   As to security, port Police Chief Patrick Kasnick said the
airport garage is as safe as the surrounding community.


   Not counting crimes involving its rental cars, he said Sea-Tac's
garage has one-fourth as much crime

results.content:
NEW YORK, HOLDING BOMB SUSPECTS, TIGHTENS SECURITY 



   NEW YORK _ As the Yankees limbered up for their game against the
Seattle Mariners Saturday afternoon, edging toward their 100th win
this year, 55,000 fans walked through a labyrinth of uniformed
officers who searched their bags and studied their faces for signs
of trouble.


   In Flushing Meadows, Queens, 33,000 tennis fans entering the
U.S. Open on Saturday for Arthur Ashe Day also had their bags
checked, while at Kennedy International Airport, travelers were
greeted by beefed-up police patrols and bomb-sniffing dogs that
investigated unattended package and cars.


   These were some of the latest moves to tighten security around
possible terrorist targets in New York City, where two suspects in
the Aug. 7 bombing of the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, are being
detained. The measures were begun shortly after the bombing, but
ratcheted up quickly with the news that the suspects would be
facing trial here.


   What began with identification checks and barriers of red-velvet
ropes stretching out of the entrances to important city buildings,
like the Police Headquarters at 1 Police Plaza, quickly took on the
appearance of large-scale construction.


   Traffic has been backed up or rerouted on several streets in
lower Manhattan over the last three days, as trucks brought in huge
concrete barriers to be erected around police headquarters, federal
buildings and City Hall. Parts of Pearl Street, which leads to the
federal court and the Metropolitan Correction Center, have been
closed from Madison Street to Park Row, with police officers posted
on the perimeter.


   Garbage bins in the area have been locked shut, while
bomb-sniffing dogs have sometimes been seen walking the street near
the detention center, which holds Mohamed Rashed Daoud 'Owhali and
Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, the two suspects in the Nairobi bombing that
killed at least 247 people, including 12 Americans.


   Barriers were also being installed at the Metro-Tech Center in
Brooklyn, which houses the Fire Department headquarters and the
city's 911 emergency system, said a fire official who spoke on
condition of anonymity. He added that a wooden barrier erected to
stop cars from entering a parking garage in the center had been
replaced days ago with a sheet of steel mesh that has to be raised
before cars are allowed inside and that guards were checking
credentials.


   Marilyn Mode, a Police Department spokeswoman, said that other
precautions, including more street closings, may be taken. But she
added that the barricades and other security measures were not
being taken because of any known terrorism threat.


   Bill Dempsey, a spokesman for the U.S. Marshals Service, said
that his people ``have been on alert status with all the activity
going on in New York, and we are taking any and all necessary
precautions to assure the security of the judiciary.''


   Some of the latest precautions are at the city's airports and
sporting events. One Port Authority police officer at Kennedy
Airport, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that the number
of officers patrolling the city's airports had been increased to
levels comparable to those in the Persian Gulf war, with about
one-third more officers being assigned to watch for suspicious
activity and answer calls about unattended packages.


   ``We're getting a lot more calls right now, to unattended bags
and cars,'' he said. ``There's a lot more private security both
inside and outside the terminals, and instead of a left bag being
routine, people are now calling them in. They don't want to take
chances anymore.''

results.content:
&HT;   



   ATLANTA _ Tight-lipped in the best of times about possible
terrorist activity in Georgia, state and federal officials are
virtually mute about the potential during this holiday season.


   Officials here are not saying much about the threat, but what
they are saying appears to be an effort to downplay the national
hysteria building since the arrest in Washington state last week of
a 32-year-old Algerian carrying bomb-making materials in his car.


   ``The possibility of terrorism has always been in our Y2K
planning,'' Mary Hudak, spokeswoman for the Federal Emergency
Management Agency's Atlanta office, said Wednesday.


   FEMA and the Georgia Emergency Management Agency will begin
staffing their respective operations centers around the clock next
week to monitor and respond to possible problems from the Y2K
computer bug, something that has been in the works for more than a
year.


   At Hartsfield International Airport, security will remain at
level 3, where it has been since the 1996 Olympics, said Lanii
Thomas, airport spokeswoman.


   That means curbside parking is prohibited, unattended bags will
be confiscated and passengers are required to present a photo ID at
the ticket counter.


   The Atlanta Police Department will have bomb-sniffing dogs at
the airport, ``but we are not at liberty to discuss in detail the
things we are doing behind the scenes to keep the airport and
passengers safe.''


   Tanya Wagner, spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation
Administration's Atlanta office, said the federal agency has not
asked airports to increase security in response to the potential
for terrorism.


   ``What we've done is ask airports and the aviation industry as a
whole to be extra diligent in performing those security measures
that are normally in place,'' Wagner said.


   Georgia Bureau of Investigation spokesman John Bankhead said
Wednesday that every agent will be on duty or on alert over the
holidays, ``but that's what has been planned for some time. This is
not a reaction to things that happened out west.''


   The Georgia State Patrol and local law enforcement agencies also
will beef up staffing shortly after Christmas, but that also was
planned as a response to Y2K.


   Bob Finke, a senior security consultant with IPSA International,
Inc. in Atlanta, said Americans should be particularly vigilant
this holiday season because of the recent arrest in Washington and
repeated threats against the United States by terrorist leader
Osama bin Laden.


   Americans tend to let down their guard during the holidays and
might be more inclined to do so as 1999 becomes 2000, he said.


   ``The unfortunate part about our country is we have a
target-rich environment and we can't protect it all. Terrorists say
law enforcement and security experts have to be lucky all the time.
Terrorists only have to be lucky once,'' Finke said.


   Celestine Armstead, spokeswoman for the Atlanta office of the
FBI, would not say if additional agents are being called to duty
because of the increased threat from terrorism or Y2K. ``We're
going to be adequately staffed to address the situation,'' Armstead
said.


   Lt. Col. Ken Baldowski, spokesman for the Georgia National
Guard, said no special precautions are being made beyond what is in
place for Y2K and problems it may cause.


   He also pointed out that a 22-member unit that specializes in
assisting after terrorist attacks involving weapons of mass
destruction is now in place at Dobbins Air Reserve Base. Known as
the 4th Military Support Detachment, the unit would be called in to
identify what explosives or toxic agents were used and then request
assistance from the appropriate federal and state agencies.


   Baldowski said the unit will not be on any higher state of alert
over the holidays. ``No more than they normally are. Their people
can be gathered very, very quickly,'' he said.


   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers


   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service
