1998-08-06 
 Uganda Civil Aviation Industry Booms 


KAMPALA, August 6 (Xinhua)-- The civil aviation industry in
Uganda has boomed in recent years, a media report said here
Thursday.


Considering the importance of the transport industry, the
government of the landlocked country undertook to establish an
autonomous Civil Aviation Au (CAA) in 1991 to
develop and promote safe, secure, regular and efficient air
transport services in the country.


More international carriers are operating in and out of the
country, scheduled operators increased from eight in 1991 to 13
in 1997, while many existing ones increased frequency.


Cargo through Entebbe International Airport has recorded an
average growth rate of 28.2 percent per annum since 1991, rising
from 6,589 tons to 26,926 tons in 1997.


International passenger traffic through Entebbe International
Airport has also increased from 118,529 in 1991 to 326,265 in
1997 at an average growth rate of 18.7 percent per annum.


The boost in tourism has tremendously enhanced the domestic
passenger traffic at an average growth rate of 37.1 percent per
annum since 1992.


The Ugandan government has taken measures to promote the air
transport, including rehabilitation of the passenger terminal
building, the supply of new air navigation equipment and
communication systems.

Airplane ordered back because of security breach


	   HONG KONG (AP) _ Officials at Hong Kong's troubled new airport
are investigating a lapse in which passengers were allowed to board
a flight without going through security checks, a spokesman said
Tuesday.
	   Flight CA652 of Taiwan's national carrier, China Airlines, was
ordered to turn back shortly before taking off last Saturday when
security guards discovered the breach. Airline staff allowed nearly
40 passengers from Kuala Lumpur in transit to Taipei to disembark
and walk directly into the departure lounge.
	   ``This was clearly a flagrant violation of airport security,''
said Airport Authority spokesman Chris Donnolley. ``The
responsibility for that incident rests squarely with the airline.''
	   Donnolley said security guards notified the control tower
immediately, and the airline was ordered back to the terminal
shortly before takeoff.
	   He did not say what measures the airport would take against the
airline, but said an investigation was going on.
	   Officials at China Airlines in Hong Kong said no one was
available Tuesday who could comment on the report.
	   All passengers going into the departure hall at Hong Kong's new
dlrs 20 billion Chek Lap Kok airport are required to go through
security checks. Transit passengers are required to disembark with
all others and have to go through another set of checks before
entering the departure hall.
	   Shortly after the opening of the airport on July 6, the Dutch
airline KLM revealed that one of its planes bound for Amsterdam had
taken off with the bags of two passengers who weren't aboard.

results.content:
1999-03-10 17:42:11 
 washington 
 FAA To Check Security at Airports 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Administration plans to  
scrutinize access to secured areas at major airports after auditors 
in a survey of five airports found inadequate safeguards for 
keeping out unauthorized personnel. 


	For the next six weeks, FAA officials will look into compliance  
by the nation's 78 largest commercial airports and their airlines 
for controlling secured areas. 


	At the end of that period, the agency will decide if it needs to  
do ``red team testing'' -- such as sending undercover agents to try 
to penetrate security -- to ensure that lapses have been addressed. 


	``We decided it would be worthwhile to look at the issue of  
access to non-public areas of airports on a broader scale,'' FAA 
spokesman Eliot Brenner said Wednesday. Once the larger airports 
are checked, officials will then look at smaller commercial 
airports, he said. 


	The FAA's security crackdown follows tests by federal agents at  
five major airports. Testifying before the House Appropriations 
Committee's panel on transportation and related agencies, the 
auditors reported Wednesday they were able to bypass secured areas 
and even board the planes. 


	``In a high percentage of tests involving airport access  
controls, our successful penetration of secure areas almost always 
resulted in our boarding an aircraft,'' said Alexis Stefani, the 
Transportation Department's deputy assistant inspector general for 
aviation. 


	Stefani told lawmakers many of the problems found in a similar  
audit in 1993 still exist. For example, he said, undercover 
personnel could enter through emergency exits and penetrate air 
cargo facilities by following airport personnel through access 
control points. 


	The majority of individuals encountered by the agents failed to  
challenge them for unauthorized access and in some cases, airport 
law enforcement officials failed to respond to emergency door 
alarms. At two airports, undercover auditors bypassed passenger 
screening checkpoints and entered the concourse. 


	Stefani attributed the ``human element'' as the primary weakness  
in keeping unauthorized personnel out of secured areas. 


	The FAA's inspection and testing of airport security also needs  
strengthening, Stefani said. 


	The agency sets guidelines and establishes procedures for  
security, while airports are responsible for controlling access to 
secured areas within the facility. Airlines oversee passengers and 
cargo. Airports and airlines together have historically been 
responsible for maintaining security equipment and systems. 


	In a letter sent to airports, Retired Adm. Cathal Flynn, the  
FAA's associate administrator for civil aviation security, said 
unauthorized personnel sneaking past controlled access is a serious 
security problem. 


	``Allowing intruders to piggy-back through access doors, not  
challenging intruders on the ramp, and intruders being able to get 
aboard aircraft combine to make a significant vulnerability,'' 
Flynn wrote. 


	He suggested that ``redundant measures, such as guarding the  
individual aircraft,'' could be required if the problems persist. 


	The Dallas Morning News reported in its Wednesday editions that  
federal agents were able to get through security doors 46 times at 
four major airports, walk around on the tarmac and board 51 
airplanes unchallenged.

results.content:
1999-09-13 13:00:25 
 usa 
 Airport Security Tightened in Miami 


	MIAMI (AP) -- The Miami airport is tightening security after two  
drug smuggling busts, requiring workers to carry see-through bags 
and to undergo inspections as they enter and leave restricted 
areas. 


	Miami-Dade County Mayor Alex Penelas said his goal is to make  
the airport a model of security. 


	``In effect, we will treat airport employees as we treat the  
flying public,'' Penelas said. ``And in some instances, we will 
treat employees even stricter than we do passengers.'' 


	The new measures that went into effect Monday will include  
random inspections of all vehicles leaving the airfield at 
checkpoints staffed by airport security personnel, Customs and 
Miami-Dade Police K-9 units. 


	Seven checkpoints will include X-ray machines and metal  
detectors by the end of the year. 


	Airport officials intend to issue the transparent bags in the  
next 60 days. 


	Workers also will be required to log in and out and will not  
have access to restricted areas when they are off duty. 


	The reforms come after two stings, on Aug. 25 and then last  
Thursday. 


	In the first bust, 58 employees -- many of them American Airline  
baggage handlers and other ground crew members -- were charged with 
smuggling drugs, hand grenades and guns onto passenger jets. In the 
second, 15 workers for other companies were charged with smuggling 
cocaine aboard planes. 


	In both cases, ramp workers used their security badges to gain  
access to airfields and restricted areas, carrying their goods 
inside knapsacks on work shifts and days off.

results.content:
1996-07-10 
 China Issues Regulations On Civil Aviation Security 


BEIJING, July 10 (Xinhua) -- Foreign air carriers that operate
routes to China must submit plans detailing their civil aviation
security to Chinese authorities, in accordance with air safety
regulations issued here today.


The civil aviation security regulations, signed by Premier Li
Peng, went into effect July 6. They include six chapters and 40
articles.


The first chapter, with eight articles, lists general
principles. It says the regulations are applicable to all civil
aviation activities within the border of the People's Republic of
China, and to all units and individuals involved in those
activities.


The first chapter also requires that all those entering the
airport must obey the laws and regulations for civil aviation, and
lists measures that operators of airports and airplanes must take
to ensure security.


The second through fourth chapters stipulate security
requirements for airports during ticket sales and baggage
consignment, on-board activities, and security checks.


According to the articles, airports cannot open for service
until they meet requirements for security personnel, airport
layout, firefighting and security facilities, and emergency
equipment.


The regulations stipulate a crew commander is required to be in
charge of on-board security to ensure flight safety, and crew
members must assist the commander to control behaviors that might
obstruct the normal flight process.


The fifth chapter lists punishments for behaviors that go
against the regulations. Fines for units and individuals will not
exceed 50,000 yuan and 5,000 respectively, and violators will be
held legally responsible for their actions.


The sixth chapter explains terms mentioned in previous
chapters.

results.content:
U.S. RECONSIDERS AIRPORT SECURITY PLAN CALLED DISCRIMINATORY 



   WASHINGTON _ The Transportation Department is rethinking a plan
to test whether an airport security measure discriminates against
members of minority groups after the Arab American Institute
complained that the test was worse than the problem it was supposed
to detect.


   The institute objected to the department's plan to ask
passengers about their religion and ethnic background to help
determine whether they were being unfairly singled out by security
officers. The institute complained that asking the questions would
contribute to the perception that Arabs were unfairly viewed as
suspects.


   The security measure, adopted by the Federal Aviation
Administration in late 1997, is called the Computer-Assisted
Passenger Prescreening System. Using secret criteria, it identifies
passengers about whom enough is known so that they are not
subjected to extra security measures, including searches of checked
baggage or more careful scanning of carry-ons.


   Before the system was introduced, Arab Americans and others
complained that it might unfairly single out people because of
their race, ethnic background or religious beliefs. The FAA said
that for security reasons it would not say what the selection
criteria were. But the agency said the criteria did not include
race or religion, and the Justice Department, after conducting a
review, agreed.


   In December 1999, however, the Transportation Department, the
FAA's parent agency, said it would test the prescreening system for
what it called ``disparate impact'' _ meaning that certain ethic
groups received disparate treatment. To do that, the department
said it would survey planeloads of people at six or seven airports,
starting with Detroit, beginning as early as April, and focusing on
flights to Europe that connected with flights to the Middle East.


   The idea was to determine the ethnicity and religion of everyone
on the flight, to get from the airlines data on who had been
subjected to extra screening and then to determine ``whether the
selection criteria in fact have a disparate impact,'' according to
a plan the Transportation Department sent the Arab group.


   The department drafted a form asking passengers for their name,
sex, race, ``ethnicity/national origin,'' religion and citizenship.
It asked the Arab group for help in winning the cooperation of Arab
and Arab American passengers.


   But James Zogby, president of the Arab American Institute, said
he had asked the department to drop the survey idea.


   ``Everybody knows we're already viewed as suspect,'' Zogby said.
``If you live in a country where you feel you are judged guilty
because of ethnicity or religion, and then you ask about ethnicity
and religion, you're asking for a form of self-incrimination.''


   ``Their intention is good,'' he added, ``but there has to be a
less intrusive way to do this.''


   Bill Adams, a spokesman for the Transportation Department, said
the department was listening to the complaints, but was determined
to carry out some kind of test.


   ``Our interest is security,'' Adams said, adding: ``We won't
tolerate discrimination.''


   Because of the complaints, he said the department was not
certain it would proceed with the survey as originally planned.


   Zogby said the computerized system had turned out to be less
offensive than the system that preceded it, which was a secret set
of criteria applied by airline personnel. Women with veils or head
coverings and men with beards who appeared Arab were much more
likely to be subjected to extra security measures when the judgment
was made by a person than when it was made by a computer, he said.


   Although the list of criteria is secret, FAA officials have said
it includes factors like a passenger's travel history, which
experts say could, in fact, bring more scrutiny to people who
travel regularly to Middle Eastern countries.

results.content:
NEW YORK _ After TWA Flight 800 exploded off Long Island in July
1996, initial fears that the jumbo jet had been brought down by a
terrorist bomb prompted the Clinton administration and Congress to
demand that security at the nation's airports be improved.


   Legislation was adopted. A down payment of $400 million was
appropriated for bomb detection machines. The Federal Aviation
Administration was given several months to produce a report on how
to redesign the country's air travel security system. A commission
headed by Vice President Al Gore urged airlines to pay their
security personnel better wages to upgrade the quality of
performance.


   But more than three years later, as investigators are again
asking whether a plane fell from the sky because of a mechanical
failure or an act of sabotage, critics of the FAA and the airline
industry, within and outside of government, say the safety
improvements achieved at airports across the country have been
modest at best.


   The FAA, for example, took two years, not three months, to
produce its report on how the industry and its regulators could
better ensure security; the $1 million state-of-the-art detection
devices used to examine baggage at 80 airports are being badly
underused, according to a 1999 government audit; that same audit
also found that efforts to limit access to airplanes on the ground
by unauthorized people was no better than it had been three years
ago.


   ``When you talk about progress since 1996, I don't think much
has been done,'' said a former member of the Gore Commission who
worked for months on pushing reforms and who spoke on the condition
of anonymity.


   Of course officials now believe that TWA Flight 800 was not
brought down by a bomb, and there is no evidence that EgyptAir 990,
the Boeing 767 that tumbled out of the sky last Sunday morning
shortly after taking off from Kennedy International Airport, was
the victim of sabotage.


   But there is no evidence, either, that a mechanical failure
caused the EgyptAir crash. And so as the search for an answer goes
on, investigators are interviewing security personnel at JFK and at
Los Angeles International Airport, the 767's initial takeoff site,
examining passenger lists and, in their own urgent way, taking
stock of whether things at the airports are any better than they
were in 1996.


   For their part, the FAA and airline officials point out that no
airplane departing from the United States has ever been destroyed
by a bomb. And they add that they have, in fact, made progress in
improving security _ though some delays were unavoidable _ and that
they are using the high-tech baggage checkers as frequently as is
practically possible.


   And there are legislators who support the claims of progress.


   Rep. James Oberstar of Minnesota, who is the ranking Democrat on
the House Transportation Committee, said the FAA was doing ``a very
good job.''


   But the evidence shows that the problems the agency has faced in
beefing up security are similar to those that have plagued it
before, most famously in its long-delayed efforts to modernize the
nation's air traffic control system. The agency, according to its
critics and even some of its supporters, is often immobilized by
its attempts to seek consensus among the various public and private
interests it is supposed to be regulating.


   One priority established after the crash of TWA Flight 800 was
the greater use of high-technology explosive-detection devices. In
the fall of 1996, Congress appropriated $144 million for the FAA to
buy the machines.


   To date, 136 of a total of 400 explosive-detection devices, each
costing about $1 million, have been deployed at 80 airports. In
addition, about 600 machines that are used to detect traces of
explosives in carry-on luggage are also in use.


   But an audit by the Department of Transportation's inspector
general published earlier this year found that the machines were
vastly underused by airlines, which are responsible for screening
baggage. The report _ which assessed a variety of security

results.content:
LAXPLANS SECURITY UPGRADE



   LOS ANGELES _ After U.S. raids Thursday in Afghanistan and
Sudan, security measures at Los Angeles International Airport were
tightened and police said they would monitor the local situation
for any potential problems.


   ``In conjunction with the Federal Aviation Administration, we
are tightening our security,'' LAX spokesman Scott Reed said,
advising passengers to expect some delays due to closer screening
of baggage and other materials.


   Los Angeles Police Department officials said the city does not
see any need to activate the downtown Emergency Operation Center
but that officials will watch for any problems with local groups.


   The Port of Los Angeles already has tightened security as the
result of past threats and will not be making any changes,
spokeswoman Julia Nagano said.


   ``We already use extreme caution with any of the goods that come
into the port,'' she said.


   Reed said the precautions being taken are similar to those that
began in 1995 with a threat from the Unabomber.


   ``Passengers should be prepared to turn on all electronic
equipment and tell security if they have something in their
carry-on bags such as toy guns or lighters that resemble guns,''
Reed said.


   Some activities at LAX were disrupted during the past several
weeks due to security concerns. Last weekend, a terminal was
evacuated when a guard spotted a gun-shaped lighter. Earlier,
operations were shut down in a terminal after a gun was discovered
in a woman's bag.

results.content:
PROTESTER: AIRLINE SECURITY POLICY TARGETS BLACKS 



   Manuel Gray entered Sky Harbor International Airport's Terminal
4 in a suit and tie and a crisply pressed white shirt, holding a
designer garment bag and matching carry-on.


   A social worker who stands 6-foot-4 and has impeccable posture
and a shaved head, Gray passed smoothly through the airport's X-ray
checkpoint.


   He's also Black.


   And he says that's the main reason a Southwest Airlines employee
pulled him and a friend, also African-American, out of line at the
boarding gate and announced that she needed to search their
luggage.


   Right there. On the counter top. In front of all the other
passengers in the terminal.


   ``She pulled out all my underwear and toiletries,'' said Gray, a
father of three who coaches YMCA youth leagues and volunteers at
his daughters' school.


   ``I've never been so humiliated,'' he said of the February 1997
incident. ``I'm the ultimate clean-cut guy.''


   Afterward, he watched dozens of people get boarding passes. No
one else was searched, he said.


   Gray claims he is a victim of ``racial profiling,'' in which
minorities are said to be targeted because of the color of their
skin.


   Saturday, Gray took his protest back to the scene of his
embarrassment, picketing with three others outside Terminal 4 with
signs with such messages as ``Southwest Airlines supports consumer
racism.''


   He also has a lawsuit pending against the airline in U.S.
District Court in Phoenix seeking $15 million in damages for
emotional distress, discrimination, harassment and other related
claims.


   His is part of a growing wave of complaints about the so-called
profiling practice.


   With airline security tightening amid terrorist bombings and the
TWA Flight 800 crash, minorities are feeling the squeeze at the
airport, according to news reports in such media outlets as ``USA
Today'' and ``CNN''.


   Last year, Laurence Boze, a Black lawyer and past president of
the National Bar Association, complained when his luggage was
searched in front of other travelers at Baltimore/Washington
International Airport.


   A US Airways gate agent reportedly told him he was detained
because he fit a profile designed to increase security at airports.


   Civil liberties groups have reported a rise in complaints from
Arab Americans and Black passengers saying they were targeted for
airport luggage searches, news reports say.


   When members of President Clinton's race panel discussed racial
profiling by law enforcement officials, moderator and Harvard Law
School Professor Charles J. Ogletree Jr. told of his experience
traveling the world as a Black man.


   He said he had been stopped numerous times by airport drug
enforcement officers who suspected him of drug trafficking.


   Courts have said that race can be among the factors used in
determining whether a suspect should be questioned, but several
panelists suggested that can result in discrimination.


   After Gray was searched last year at Sky Harbor, he demanded to
know why he was searched. Through his questioning of the female
airline employee, he learned that he fit a profile set by the
Federal Aviation Administration, he said.


   ``She basically told us we paid in cash, we looked suspicious,
and we were African-American,'' said Gray, 39.


   Southwest Airline officials could not be reached for comment
Saturday at their corporate office in Dallas. Other airline and
airport employees, however, said race is not a criterion used to
determine whether to search a passenger.


   Airline employees are prohibited from disclosing the criteria.
But employees and news reports point to several red flags: paying
with cash, buying a one-way ticket, purchasing a ticket within 48
hours of a departure time and booking a flight with no connections.


   Usually, a targeted individual fits at least two of the criteria
in order for a search, one airport employee said.


   Gray said he paid for his $39 ticket with cash, although he
booked the round-trip flight two weeks in advance.


   If peop

results.content:
1996-09-10 
 Clinton Asks for More Funds to Fight Terrorism 


WASHINGTON, September 9 (Xinhua) -- U.S. President Bill Clinton
today called on Congress to provide more than 1 billion dollars to
employ more Federal Bureau of Investigation agents to fight
terrorism and to improve U.S. airline security in general.


"Terrorists don't wait and neither should we," Clinton told
reporters at a White House ceremony at which he received a report
on airport security and urged Congress to act before it adjourns
in October.


Clinton asked for the report after the July 17 crash of TWA
Flight 800, which exploded over the Atlantic Ocean off New York,
killing all 230 people on board.


Vice President Al Gore, who chaired the White House Commission
on Aviation Safety and Security that wrote the report, announced
the major points of its report last week. The panel's
recommendations included a call for better bomb detection
equipment, profiling of passengers, matching passengers to their
baggage, increased use of bomb-sniffing dogs and running
background checks on employees with access to secure airport
areas.


Endorsing all these measures, Clinton said he wanted Congress
to provide money to go beyond the narrow issue of airline security
and fight terrorism more broadly at home and abroad.


"Shortly I will submit to Congress a budget request for more
than 1 billion dollars to expand our FBI anti-terrorism forces and
to put the most sophisticated bomb detection machines in America's
airports," he said.


Clinton said he would direct that all airport and airline
employees with access to secure areas be subjected to criminal
background checks. He also said he would require matching all
passengers to their bags and increased use of bomb-sniffing dogs
at certain airports.

results.content:
1998-08-22 
 U.S. Tightens Security Nationwide Following Missile Attacks 


WASHINGTON, August 21 (Xinhua) -- The United States has
tightened security around the nation in the wake of its missile
attacks against what it claimed to be terrorist facilities in
Afghanistan and Sudan on Thursday.


The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) of the United States
on Friday ordered tighter security on airports. Security for
Government buildings and military bases around the country also
were tightened as a precaution against retaliation from groups
that the U.S. targeted.


The FAA cited information from law enforcement and intelligence
agencies about new terrorist threats but cautioned that the new
security measures do not reflect any specific threats at airports.


"These are prudent and precautionary steps to ensure the safety
of travelers," said FAA spokesman Eliot Brenner.


The measures include increased canine bomb sniffing units and
additional use of trace explosive detector units at security
checkpoints, curbside parking restrictions and posting agency
inspectors at airports in the United States and abroad to monitor
security operations for domestic carriers.


The agency has cautioned airlines to be mindful of
discriminatory practices and not to target passengers based on
ethnicity or religious affiliations during screenings.


Military bases around the country went to what is known as
Threat Condition Alpha, the first of four levels of increased
security instituted when there is a general threat of terrorist
activity.


The Nuclear Regulatory Commission as a precaution advised
operators of the nation's 110 atomic power plants and university
research reactors to step up security.


In Washington D.C., tourists and commuters boarding subways
were told over intercoms that a security alert was in effect and
"not to leave unattended items in Metrorail stations and trains"
and to report any suspicious items, activities or persons.


Extra police and closer inspections of identification and
packages greeted people entering government buildings and
landmarks.


At the State Department, cars and trucks were parked across the
entrances to two driveways. The horseshoe-shaped drives were long
ago closed to ordinary traffic as a precaution against car
bombers.


The Secret Service also added guards around various diplomatic
missions.


The FBI nonetheless issued a general security warning. "It is
reasonable and prudent to conclude that yesterday (Thursday)'s
action by the United States elevates the risk to U.S. interests
worldwide," the agency said in a statement.


The United States said that its cruise missile attacks were
both retaliation for the fatal bombings at two U.S. embassies in
Africa two weeks ago and prevention of future terrorism against
the U.S.

results.content:
1999-05-10 06:45:18 
 usa 
 Northwest Fined for Security Breach 


	ROMULUS, Mich. (AP) -- Northwest Airlines paid or has pending  
more than $120,000 in fines for security breaches at Detroit 
Metropolitan Airport in the past two years, federal records show. 
Twice, agents were able to sneak dynamite bombs past airport 
checkpoints. 


	Northwest has paid $21,500 in settling four breaches since 1997  
and has $99,000 in finds pending for nine other lapses, The Detroit 
News reported today, citing Federal Aviation Administration records 
obtained through the Freedom of Information Act. A 14th violation 
was found but the level of fine was not yet set. 


	Among violations cited in the records:  


	--On Aug. 24, 1997, Northwest flew the checked bag of a federal  
aviation agent on a flight from the airport to Toronto. The special 
agent wasn't on the flight or any other headed to Toronto. 
Northwest settled the complaint for $5,000. 


	--Undercover FAA agents successfully sneaked dynamite bombs  
through checkpoints during September 1997 tests -- once because a 
security guard was talking to a co-worker instead of looking at a 
monitor to check a briefcase's contents. The airline paid $10,500 
in fines. 


	--A Nov. 6 security breach prompted by an unidentified man who  
avoided a checkpoint and walked through an exit-only door after a 
security guard failed to watch the door while reading a book. Fines 
were pending. 


	FAA officials told the News that the number of citations was  
relatively high, though they stressed it can vary based on the 
number of undercover operations conducted at an airport. 


	FAA regional spokesman Tony Molinaro said the agency is ``much  
happier with the airport's security plan in the past three 
months,'' since a new security company was hired and safety 
measures were enhanced. 


	In March, Northwest canceled the contract of its security  
company, Atlanta-based Argenbright Security Inc., in favor of 
Huntleigh Corp., which took over April 1. 


	Northwest spokesman Jon Austin declined to address specific  
incidents, noting that fines are routinely reduced. 


	``We're always concerned about security and work daily with the  
FAA on the subject,'' he said. ``We want the FAA to test our 
procedures and personnel so that we can identify and implement 
improvements.'' 


	Dave Katz, Wayne County's airport director, said the change in  
companies has enhanced Northwest's security. 


	``We get more than a million passengers in here a month. It's  
pretty hard to bat 100 percent when it comes to security,'' he 
said. ``This is a safe airport, and Northwest is a safe airline.'' 


	Linda Newman, an Argenbright spokeswoman in Atlanta, did not  
return several telephone calls, the News reported.

results.content:
1997-05-16 
 Portuguese Airport Rejects Responsibility for Accident 


LISBON, May 15 (Xinhua) -- The Francisco sa Carneiro airport,
in the north of the capital, rejected any responsibility today for
the accident occurred Wednesday to a Regional Airlines Spanish
company plane.


Fernando Vierra, director of the airport, said that it "was not
caused by problems in the airport," referring to refurbishing of
the taxiing airstrips started a week ago that caused a shortening
of some 550 meters.


"The works are being done with all the obligatory security
measures and they will continue that way," said Fernando Vieira.


The plane, coming from Madrid, lost one wheel and a stabilizer
and slid several yards when landing.


Only a woman among the 34 passengers and three crew members
suffered a slight injury, and the airport activities
returned to normal today.

results.content:
1996-03-22 21:36 
 US Warns of Insufficient Security at Athens Airport 


WASHINGTON, March 22 (Xinhua) -- The United States today warned
American travelers of cautiously using the Hellenikon International
Airport in the Greek capital of Athens.


U.S. Federal Transportation Secretary Federico Pena said in a
statement that the Hellenikon Airport does not meet international
standards for security and all the U.S. airliners issuing tickets
for travel between the United States and Athens must advise
passengers of the finding.


The announcement came after a team of U.S. Federal Aviation
Administration security analysts visited the Hellenikon Airport.
But details of the investigations were not released.


The Transportation Department said that it raised the security
issue of the Hellenikon Airport several months ago and the Greek
authorities concerned has been making efforts to improve the
security conditions in accordance with the International Civil
Aviation Authority standards.


But Pena said that security improvement is not yet sufficient
although progress is being made at the Hellenikon Airport.


A Greek government spokesman said in Athens that Greece and
the United States are cooperating in improving the security
conditions at the airport.


He pledged that the improvement work will continue until "a
perfect level of security" is achieved.

results.content:
A BIG THUMBS UP TO THOSE WHO HELP 




   The flight from Houston to Atlanta had landed right on schedule.
But because our arrival gate was occupied _ an all-too-familiar
predicament _ we were idling on the tarmac between terminals,
waiting until space cleared.


   My immediate reaction was irritation. How is it that mankind is
brilliant enough to build machines that fly so high and so fast,
yet we can't supply sufficient parking on the ground?


   And because of this absurdity, how many of us would miss our
tight flight connections?


   Then my gaze focused on the beehive of activity below, on scores
of carts and trucks scooting across the pavement and carrying
literally thousands of pieces of luggage.


   For a scant moment, my dismay intensified. My bags probably
wouldn't make the connection, either, I convinced myself. And by
the way: Are these the same guys who knocked a wheel off my new
suitcase the last time I traveled through Hartsfield International?


   But as time passed, I ceased bemoaning our temporary fate and
instead began marveling at the men and women driving these baggage
vehicles, working frantically to ensure that the possessions of
tens of thousands of passengers each day reach their appointed
destinations.


   The wonder isn't that an occasional bag is misdirected or
damaged; it's that these occurrences are so infrequent, especially
given the pace and scope of modern-day travel.


   &QL; 
SILENT HELPERS &QL;


   Amid all the hassles, it's easy to become frustrated. To
complain. And to overlook countless individuals whose efforts _
often in anonymity _ help make our trips less stressful. Safer.
More enjoyable.


   Consider the plight of security personnel at airports and other
public places. They go to work every day in a pressure-packed
environment. A dangerous environment, too, as we were reminded by
two tragic deaths at the U.S. Capitol this summer.


   With security measures tightened at airports in the aftermath of
recent terrorist bombings and subsequent threats, all travelers are
subject to inconveniences and delays. But these men and women are
there for our protection. And when a security guard takes five
minutes to inspect my computer or camera equipment, I'm not
aggravated; I'm comforted by his or her diligence.


   &QL; 
KUDOS &QL; 
 &QL;


   Here's a tip of the cap, too, to other unsung heroes of travel:


   Park rangers and volunteers dedicated to preserving _ and
showing off _ our natural and historical wonders.


   Volunteers at tourist information centers and information booths
who relish introducing us to their hometown treasures _ out of a
sense of pride, not a desire for compensation.


   Tour-bus drivers. We deservedly reward tour guides. But the
driver who gets us safely to each destination too often goes
unthanked.


   Busboys on cruise ships and in restaurants. At sea, the busboy
gets half the gratuity traditionally offered a waiter and often
works twice as hard. At least we usually know his name; in
restaurants on land we're rarely introduced.


   Housekeepers in hotels. We trust them with our valued
possessions as we go sightseeing or attend business meetings, and
almost without exception they never let us down. But how often do
we ask their name? Or leave a thank-you tip?


   Individuals in airports and at other public venues who transport
travelers with disabilities and elderly or injured travelers on
carts and in wheelchairs. Some are airport or airline personnel;
others are volunteers. All provide an important service.


   Ticket and gate agents at airports and bus and train stations.
It's not their fault our flight or bus is delayed or canceled or
overbooked. But they sure are convenient targets for venting our
emotions, aren't they?


   I could go on and on: the gardener in a public park, the
naturalist at a zoo or aquarium, the museum guide, the theater
usher, the flight attendant.


   I made my connection in Atlanta. So did my luggage. I don't know
whom to thank. But he or she is appreciated. &QL; 
 &QL; 
XXXXEND OF STORY &QL;

results.content:
2000-07-31 
 Capital Airport Mobilized to Fight Human Trafficking 


BEIJING, July 31 (Xinhua) -- The Capital International Airport
of Beijing has adopted a series of measures to fight against human
trafficking through the airport.


The airport's leading group against human trafficking convened
a meeting here today, calling for joint efforts from the police,
the civil aviation industry, border patrol and customs departments.


Eleven measures and requirements were unveiled at the meeting,
which are expected to greatly strengthen the airport's fight
against human smuggling and other crimes.


Major emphasis will be placed on the crack-down of "snakeheads",
who demand high fees for taking people out of China, according to
participants at the meeting.

results.content:
1997-05-03 
 Johannesburg Airport Beefs Up Security 


JOHANNESBURG, May 2 (Xinhua) -- Security at Johannesburg
International Airport has been upgraded after media reports early
this week that crime was on the increase, the airport authorities
said today.


In its statement, the airport said it had budgeted 1.2 million
Rands (272,727 U.S. dollars) to install closed circuit security
cameras to monitor public areas, and had arranged for a more
visible police presence on the airport's premises.


The airport said it had built facilities in the domestic
terminal where the public could report crime and another was
planned for the international terminal.


It had also established a task team comprising airport
representatives, South African Airways security staff, policemen,
and private security guards to fight crimes.


Jessie Duarte, an official responsible for safety and security
in Gauteng Province said on Wednesday that there had been 10,295
crimes at the airport since 1994, with the daily number of crimes
rising from 8.5 percent in 1994 to the current 11 percent.


In addition to burglaries, the crimes at the airport also
include a variety of smugglings involving drugs, ivories,
abalones, diamonds and arms.

results.content:
1999-08-27 03:30:11 
 usa 
 Fla. Mayor Defends Airport Security 


	MIAMI (AP) -- Miami's mayor defended the security at Miami  
International Airport, where a sting operation led to the arrests 
of dozens of American Airlines workers in a suspected cocaine 
smuggling ring. 


	``Miami International Airport is a safe and secure airport,''  
Miami-Dade County Mayor Alex Penelas said Thursday. ``This airport 
meets or exceeds all federal requirements and regulations.'' 


	Fifty-nine people were indicted Wednesday in what was believed  
to be the biggest set of drug arrests involving a U.S. airline. 


	U.S. Attorney Thomas Scott, whose office led the investigation,  
criticized airport security and said airline workers had easily 
exploited their employee access. 


	The alleged smugglers hid shipments in food carts and carry-on  
luggage, and dozens of workers gained access to secure areas. 


	Penelas said the airport had increased security in the past two  
years, including limiting employee access to planes. He said 
airport officials would study further limiting that access and the 
types of bags employees are allowed to bring into secure areas.

results.content:
Indonesian authorities tighten security at airport


	   JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Indonesian authorities have tightened
security at a Jakarta airport, fearing that dozens of bankers
suspected of misusing state money may try to flee abroad.
	   Justice Minister Muladi was quoted Friday by the official Antara
news agency as saying the step was taken because most of 96 bankers
banned from leaving the country have their own private planes.
	   Muladi said immigration officers have been deployed at Halim
Perdanakusuma airport, to check the ownership of every private
plane taking off from the airstrip in the eastern Jakarta
outskirts.
	   Muladi said the measures were needed ``because it will be
difficult to regain the state money if they are able to flee.''
	   Some 96 bankers are currently under investigation as Indonesia
tries to clean up its banking system.
	   They include Bambang Trihatmodjo, a son of former President
Suharto and Mohamad ``Bob'' Hasan, a former trade minister and
longtime associate of Suharto.
	   Hasan has already testified Thursday about allegations of
misconduct at his troubled Bank Umum Nasional.
	   Police have summoned Bambang to testify on his partly owned
Andremoda Bank, which has been closed.

results.content:
AIRLINE SUES TO RID AIRPORT OF BAGGAGE SCREENING DEVICE  



   Continental Airlines filed a federal antitrust lawsuit Monday
against United Airlines and the committee that oversees operations
at Washington Dulles International Airport, contending that
recently installed baggage-sizing templates inhibit competition.


   The suit, which was filed against United and the Dulles Airport
Airline Management Council in federal court in Virginia, comes
after the installation on April 15 of the templates at X-ray
security checkpoints at Dulles.


   United, which is the largest airline at Dulles, carrying more
than 40 percent of the airport's passengers in the year ended Feb.
29, had proposed installing the templates. The carrier uses the
equipment to screen bags at 24 other U.S. airports.


   Continental, which says it has more overhead bin space on its
planes and uses that as a marketing tool to attract customers,
opposed the templates, contending they would prevent its passengers
from carrying their bags onto its aircraft.


   The ability to carry on _ rather than check _ bags has been
hotly contested in the U.S. airline industry in recent years.
Airlines like United, American and Delta have installed sizing
equipment at airports to prevent travelers from carrying excessive
amounts of baggage into aircraft cabins. Many business travelers,
in addition to Continental, oppose these measures.


   The Dulles suit is the third time Continental has fought
installation of baggage-screening devices at airports. In late
1998, the airline, which is the nation's fifth largest, sued Delta,
the No. 3 airline, in California, contending that Delta's templates
at San Diego International Airport interfered with its carry-on
policies. That case was settled out of court. Soon afterward,
Continental also threatened to sue United, the largest U.S.
airline, over United's use of templates at Denver International
Airport. The airlines settled the matter without legal action.


   In the Washington suit, Continental contends that United
``conspired with other airlines under the auspices of the Airline
Management Council to limit competition by requiring all airlines'
customers to conform to a single, restrictive standard for carry-on
baggage.''


   Continental contends that the actions of United and the council
violate antitrust law and interfere with Continental's contractual
relationships with its customers. It also says that United ``led
the conspiracy among airlines who voted in favor of installing
sizers at Dulles, preventing Continental and other carriers from
competing for customers by offering more customer-friendly carry-on
policies.'' Continental and its regional partner, Continental
Express, are seeking removal of the templates and triple damages.


   Kieran Sheridan, chairman of the Dulles Airport Airline
Management Council and Northwest's general manager at the airport,
said the decision to use the templates, which block large items
from entering X-ray machines at checkpoints, was made only after
installation was approved by the majority of members of the
council, as is required by its bylaws. Six carriers voted against
installation, he said: Continental, Continental Express, Northwest,
US Airways, Midwest Express and Virgin Atlantic.


   Sheridan said that he had received no complaints about the
templates after some initial flaws were straightened out, and that
he was ``curious about Continental's allegations about back-door
deals being made.''


   ``To my understanding, Continental was present at all meetings,
and nothing was not discussed in an open forum,'' he added.


   United declined to comment on Continental's lawsuit. Most of the
other carriers that voted against the templates said they had no
plans to take legal action.


   From a legal perspective, some experts said that Continental
might have a valid claim.


   Michael Levine, a Harvard Law School professor, former official
of the Civil Aeronautics Board and a former executive at
Continental and Northwest, said that ``in the basic thrust of
Continental's argument,

results.content:
NEW YORK TIGHTENS SECURITY AT PUBLIC BUILDINGS 



   NEW YORK _ The heightened security measures at public buildings
went almost unnoticed Friday.


   Around town, the security alert ordered by Mayor Rudolph
Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir manifested itself in
small, all but imperceptible, ways.


   At midday five Metropolitan Transportation Authority officers
were standing outside Grand Central Terminal, for example, when
normally there would be one. A New York City police officer who
usually patrols several blocks near the Port Authority Bus Terminal
was sticking close to the bus station, and two police officers had
been sent to the U.N. building to stand guard on the sidewalk.


   The officers said they were on the lookout for suspicious
packages or cars left on the street with their engines running. But
they themselves were not arousing any curiosity. ``Nobody's asked
any questions _ except directions,'' said one officer, who spoke on
the condition of anonymity.


   On Thursday, officials of the Federal Aviation Administration
and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said they were
also taking precautions because of the possible threat of
terrorism. But passengers at Kennedy International Airport and
Newark International Airport said they were puzzled by the absence
of a more visible show of security.


   ``I expected all these strict rules when I got here today,''
said Kate Doble, who was boarding a flight at Kennedy to return
home to Sydney, Australia, after working as a summer-camp counselor
in North Carolina. ``I expected to be checked or have someone go
through my bags, but they just passed me by.''


   Laurent Mercier, a French government worker who was traveling to
Los Angeles, said he was surprised that no one stopped him from
leaving unattended luggage on a seat near the United Airlines
ticket counter in Newark, N.J. ``I left my bag on the seat and went
to smoke a cigarette, and nobody said anything,'' he said.


   Mercier said that because of the military strike, he had arrived
at the airport two hours and 15 minutes before his scheduled 6:30
p.m. departure. ``If there had not been a strike, I would have gone
to the Port Authority and caught a bus at about 4:15 to get here at
5:15,'' he said.


   Earlier in the day, passengers arriving at Kennedy after an
Aeroflot flight from St. Petersburg, Russia, said they noticed
something a little out of the ordinary when they picked up their
luggage at the Delta Air Lines baggage-claim area: a beagle was
sniffing the bags. ``I've never seen that before,'' said Harry
Wilson, a political science professor from Roanoke, Va. ``But
coming through customs was easy. Customs was the same as always.''


   At the U.N. building, three security officers stood behind the
entry gate asking visitors with large packages to check them, a
normal routine. One of them, Hugh Mullaney, said that he had not
detected any heightened anxiety about the prospect of terrorism,
perhaps because memories of the 1993 bombing of the World Trade
Center are no longer fresh.


   ``It will have to start happening closer to home before people
get nervous,'' Mullaney said.


   (STORY CAN END HERE _ OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)


   Some tourists visiting the United Nations brushed off the talk
of danger. ``We're more scared in France than we are here,'' said
Valerie Nollet, a French real estate broker.


   The terrorism alert was having little effect on travel plans,
travel agents across the city said. Most people who go abroad in
late August have nonrefundable tickets and are traveling for
pleasure, rather than business, and this is not the recommended
season for travel to either Africa or the Middle East.


   Valerie Wilson, the owner of an agency that bears her name, said
that since the bombing of the U.S. embassies in Kenya and Tanzania,
about two dozen clients had inquired whether it was safe to travel,
but only one had canceled plans to go on a safari in September.


   ``People wanted to know if maybe there wasn't a stronger warning
that they hadn't heard over th

results.content:
1998-12-27 
 Security at HK International Airport Praised 


HONG KONG, December 27 (Xinhua) -- Officials of the Federal
Aviation Administration (FAA) of the United States have commented
the aviation security at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) as
"excellent" after an inspection of HKIA.


The FAA said that the security arrangement and practices at
HKIA exceeded guidelines set by the United Nations' International
Civil Aviation Organization, a press release by the Hong Kong
Airport Authority (HKAA) said here Sunday.


Security at HKIA is handled by more than 2,000 staff of the
Aviation Security Company, a subsidiary of the HKAA. In addition,
more than 400 members of the Hong Kong Police are stationed at the
Airport Police Station.


FAA officials said that the access control of the passenger
terminal and airfield perimeter is among the best of the world.


These officials were also impressed by passenger screening
arrangements, especially the large number of screening stations
and the high proficiency of security operators.


Documentation for all Airport Security Programs were well
written, comprehensive and had been effectively disseminated to
airlines, they said.


HKIA employs some of the world's most comprehensive baggage
screening. Every single item of baggage destined for the hold of
an aircraft undergoes an automated security screening called Hold
Baggage Screening, which analyses all bags as they pass through
automated smart X-ray machines, known as the Machine Automated
Explosive Detection System.

results.content:
1999-03-15 18:31:53 
 usa 
 Schiavo Defends Airport Check 


	COLUMBUS, Ohio (AP) -- The former inspector general of the  
Transportation Department defended her attempt to test airport 
security by checking a suspicious bag, saying Monday she did 
nothing wrong. 


	``I did not do anything illegal, and it's not illegal to buy a  
ticket, check a bag and not get on a plane,'' Mary Schiavo said on 
NBC's ``Today'' show. 


	Ms. Schiavo, a critic of airline safety in the United States,  
said she agreed to help a television station test security at Port 
Columbus International Airport on Friday by checking a bag that 
should have attracted the attention of security. 


	She said she was trying to prove that bags are not routinely  
X-rayed before being loaded on a plane, and that bags are sometimes 
allowed to take off without their owners on board. International 
flights do not permit unattended passenger luggage to take off. 


	Ms. Schiavo's bag, which contained a tape recorder, a can of  
shaving cream, a racquet ball can and some wiring, did not leave 
with the flight bound for Washington. It was unclear if that was 
due to airport security checks or because the television station, 
WCHM-TV, had informed the airport about the bag prior to takeoff. 


	In any event, the bag was taken to a screening area at some  
point and drew attention when X-ray screeners saw what it 
contained. The airport concourse was evacuated, and the bag was 
taken outside and investigated, shutting down a runway for four 
hours. 


	Airport officials complained that the suspicious bag disrupted  
the airport. The FBI is investigating whether any laws were broken. 
The FBI would not discuss its investigation, and the Federal 
Aviation Administration would not comment on what possible laws may 
have been broken. 


	Ms. Schiavo said she was sorry for any inconvenience ``but it  
was done by the airport with the full knowledge of what was going 
on.'' 


	The television station said the airport was informed in advance  
it would be doing a report on airport security Friday, but did not 
tell officials exactly how that was going to be done. 


	Ms. Schiavo resigned from her federal post in 1996 after  
criticizing the FAA on several occasions. Since then she has 
published a book accusing the FAA of sloppy inspections, lax 
airport security and disregard for bogus airplane parts.

results.content:
2000-03-07 
 Nepali FM Denies Security Deal With India 


KATHMANDU, March 6 (Xinhua) -- Nepali Foreign Minister Ram
Sharan Mahat Monday denied the news report that Nepal had agreed
to allow the presence of Indian security personnel at Tribhuvan
International Airport (TIA) in Kathmandu.


Replying to questions at the Parliament, Mahat made it clear
that the Nepali government had given no approval on presence of
Indian security personnel at TIA.


"The news report is false and has no truth at all," he told the
MPs.


It is the responsibility of the government to provide security
at the Nepalese airport and Nepal is quite competent to provide
such a securtiy, he stressed.


"His Majesty's government is determined to provide security in
keeping with international air safety standard at TIA," Mahat said,
adding that the existing security arrangement at the airport would
be improved according to the needs of time.


The French News Agency (AFP) Saturday quoted Indian Minister of
State for Civil Aviation Chaman Lal Gupta as saying that "Nepal
had admitted of security lapses at its international airport and
had agreed in principle to allow Indian security at the TIA."


After an Indian Airlines passenger plane was hijacked on route
from Kathmandu to New Delhi on December 24, 1999, India has
suspended its flights here on security reasons and suggested
posting security personnel at TIA, which was rejected by the
Nepali government.

results.content:
1998-04-14 
 Thai Plane Accident Under Investigation 


SHANGHAI, April 14 (Xinhua) -- Investigations into an accident
of a Thai International Airways MD-11 plane at Shanghai's Hongqiao
International Airport have begun, sources here said.


The East China Civil Aviation Bureau of the China Civil
Aviation Administration (CAAC) formed a special team to probe
into the accident in accordance with established international
practices. A group of six Thai Airways officials is expected to
join the CAAC team soon.


On-the-spot investigations into the plane, the crew, the
airport and the airport guarantee system have already started. And
a report is expected to be submitted to the international civil
aviation authorities.


The Thai aircraft veered off the runway of the Hongqiao
International Airport Sunday afternoon. The airport was closed
down temporarily because of the accident but reopened early
Monday. None of the 281 passengers on board was injured by the
accident, which, however, affected more than 100 flights and at
least 10,000 passengers.


The plane, which was towed from the site to the China Eastern
Airlines maintenance center for a safety check after the accident
is still staying at the airport. The crew went back to
Thailand Monday evening.


During the investigations, the captain of the Thai plane said
he was satisfied with measures taken by the airport authorities to
handle the accident, including the immediate aid to passengers
affected and the towing of the aircraft.

results.content:
LOS ANGELES _ United Airlines reaffirmed its pledge to decrease
flight delays at San Francisco International Airport by as much as
30 percent by this fall.


   During a wide-ranging discussion with reporters Thursday, United
Airlines President Rono J. Dutta said the carrier would attempt to
reduce delays by cutting back on the number of its flights,
reducing turn-around times for planes on the ground and scheduling
more flights during off-peak periods.


   United, which handles 55 percent of the traffic at SFO with 500
daily arrivals and departures, is implementing the measures to
appease airport officials who wanted the airline to reduce delays
by eliminating many of its short-haul flights. SFO suffers from the
worst delays of any airport in the nation.


   Dutta said many of the problems result from a confluence of
factors outside of United's control, such as the Bay Area's
ubiquitous fog and the airport's crowded, intersecting runways.


   While most major airports, such those in Chicago (where United
is based) and Los Angeles, handle an average of 110 arrivals per
hour, SFO handles only 60 in an hour. During bad weather, that
figure can drop to as low as 30.


   ``It's one of the worst-performing airports in the nation,''
Dutta said. ``Unfortunately, we get a lot of the flack for it.
That's why we keep screaming for more runway capacity.''


   Dutta said the situation at SFO speaks to a greater concern for
United and the rest of the airline industry: the need for more
runways and larger airports throughout the country.


   ``The underlying problems of delays aren't going away unless the
federal government steps up and spends more money on airport
infrastructure. We're headed for an aviation crisis.''


   Some steps are under way to address the capacity shortage at
SFO, including the opening of the new $3.2 billion International
Terminal Building, where United will have 14 new gates.


   In addition, the airport is studying the feasibility of
reconfiguring its four runways so that they are farther apart, a
move that would substantially increase air traffic.


   Dutta also spoke in detail about United's $11.6 billion merger
with US Airways, which has prompted antitrust concerns because the
combined airline would control 30 percent of the domestic market.


   Some members of Congress and consumer advocates fear the merger,
which United hopes to complete by year's end, will lead to higher
airfares, fewer choices and a deterioration in service.


   But Dutta sought to reassure the public by reiterating United's
promise to freeze airfares for two years, with exceptions for
adjustments for higher fuel costs and other inflation-related
expense.


   Alan B. Wayne, United's regional director for governmental and
public affairs based in Los Angeles, said the carrier will continue
to adjust its schedules at SFO until it achieves the 30 percent
decrease in delays by September.


   ``That's what the airport expects and that's what we're working
toward,'' Wayne said. ``We're fine-tuning our schedules in the
interest of reducing delays at the same time still meet customer
demand.''


   In the past 18 months, United has cut flights at the airport to
230 a day from 260.


   The airline also is employing time-saving techniques such as
``closed loop flying,'' which uses the same aircraft to fly various
routes.


   Still, the carrier has not consolidated its short-haul flights
and used larger planes to fly to cities such as Fresno and
Sacramento, as SFO officials have suggested. Instead Wayne said
United is opting to reduce delays through other measures.


   Dutta noted that United has not increased the number of flights
at SFO in four years. But even as the carrier takes measures to
reduce flight delays, he said, other airlines ``keep jumping in and
making the problem almost worse.''


   Dutta noted United's measures to reduce delays come ``at great
cost to us in terms of revenues and market position. We don't know
how much longer we can keep going down this path. How much more can
we shrink and make room for s

results.content:
2000-08-21 
 Beijing Airport Vows to Improve Services 


BEIJING, August 21 (Xinhua) -- Beijing's Capital International
Airport has vowed to greatly improve its services which passengers
often complain about.


Li Peiying, president of the Capital International Airport Co.
Ltd., said that effective measures will be taken to lift services
up to the international standards within three years.


According to him, the airport is working to ensure that more
than 98 percent of flights will keep to their schedules, and the
boarding procedures will be completed within five minutes for
passengers of first- and business-class cabins and 20 minutes for
passengers of economy-class seats.


He also promised that the passengers will be able to get their
first piece of luggage within 12 minutes after the arrival of a
flight, and all the luggage will be handled within 40 minutes.


In addition, the airport will try to optimize the flow of
passengers, increase guiding facilities and signs, and improve the
shopping environment as well as communications services, Li said.

results.content:
1999-05-26 11:41:43 
 usa 
 Airports Lack Security at Bag Claim 


	WASHINGTON (AP) -- Checking in at an airport, it's hard to miss  
the preoccupation with baggage security. 


	``Did you pack your own bags?'' the ticket agent asks. ``Did  
anyone ask you to carry anything on board?'' 


	It's a different story when passengers arrive at their  
destinations. 


	At some airports, such as Los Angeles International, most  
airlines will not let passengers leave baggage claim areas without 
showing a claim stub for their luggage. But at others, including 
Reagan National and Dulles International near Washington, no one 
checks. 


	Anyone can grab anything or, perhaps more worrisome for  
security, can leave a bag or package behind. The only safeguards 
are signs or public address warnings noting that many bags look 
alike so passengers should check their luggage tags. 


	In April 1998, police arrested a man who took advantage of such  
lax security at Dallas-Fort Worth Airport. They said that James 
Clarence Ringley of Arlington, Texas, stole about 500 bags from 
airline baggage belts and used the contents -- worth an estimated $1 
million -- to stock a booth at a flea market. 


	Airport police said it was the largest recovery of luggage at  
any major U.S. airport. Ringley recently received four years in 
prison. 


	``I've wondered about it a few times as I've walked out with all  
kinds of bags and nobody's checked me,'' said J.T. Maiorano of New 
York, a lighting technician who travels over 150,000 miles 
annually. 


	Standing outside the USAirways claim area at Reagan National,  
where he just picked up a garment bag unchallenged, Maiorano said, 
``I wouldn't mind at all being checked. ... I'd rather do it than 
get ripped off of my luggage.'' 


	The federal government requires the baggage questions at  
check-in and the constant reminders about unattended luggage. 


	But security at the end of a trip -- in the baggage claim areas --  
is the responsibility of individual airlines. They typically lease 
and operate baggage belts from an airport authority. Airlines, in 
turn, say they provide checkpoints where they are needed. 


	``If we don't have a high incidence of problems, we don't do  
it,'' said United Airlines spokesman Joe Hopkins. ``It helps keep 
down the cost of air travel.'' 


	Some airports like Hartsfield in Atlanta or Miami International  
provide baggage area security in many terminals as a basic service 
to their airline tenants. Atlanta, which handles 200,000 passengers 
a day, spends about $1.5 million annually on it. 


	As a result, said Hartsfield spokeswoman Lanii Thomas, the  
airport does not have a high rate of baggage theft. 


	Airports generally don't keep track of stolen bags, deferring to  
the airlines. The carriers themselves are loath to report a bag as 
stolen, preferring to say that it is ``missing.'' Often a bag that 
has been reported stolen ends up back at its intended destination 
after a journey on the wrong flight. 


	The Transportation Department tracks mishandled bags -- those  
that are lost, damaged, delayed or ``pilfered.'' In March, the 
major U.S. airlines had about five reports of mishandled bags for 
every 1,000 they handled, about the same as the year before. 


	Tightening security at baggage claim areas is not always  
foolproof. 


	In 1996, Los Angeles police arrested a man who allegedly raided  
the airline baggage belts at Los Angeles International and walked 
away with 11 sets of golf clubs, professional camera equipment, a 
snowboard and other items worth an estimated $20,000. 


	While the airport had and continues to use a bag-matching  
program, the suspect found a way around it: He wore a Delta Air 
Lines pilot uniform and a fake ID and strode confidently past the 
checkout gates.

NEWS STORY 
 2000-03-27 22:13 
 Airport Security Co. Pleads Guilty  


   MIAMI (AP) -- An airport security firm was sentenced Monday to
two years' probation and $110,000 in fines and restitution for
failing to do background checks and complete employment forms for
personnel at Miami International Airport.


   Aviation Safeguards of Florida Inc. agreed to a plea bargain in
December. The company could have faced up to $500,000 in fines and
five years' probation if convicted.


   According to court records, Aviation Safeguards failed to
complete employment verifications, including criminal history
checks, at least 70 times in 1998, then lied about the lapses to
federal regulators.


   In some cases, the employment applications and verifications
weren't completed until after employees had been given access to
secure airport areas.


   The charges stemmed from the actions of the company's former
general manager in Miami, Guillermo Blanco, who pleaded guilty last
year to 22 counts of giving false statements to the Federal
Aviation Administration.


   Aviation Safeguards provides security personnel, wheelchair
operators, luggage screeners and scanners to small airlines that do
not have their own.


   ------


   On the Net: Federal Aviation Administration: http://www.faa.gov/


   Miami International Airport: http://www.miami-airport.com/


 AP-NY-03-27-00 2213

   WASHINGTON _ High turnover among people who screen passengers
and luggage is the weakest link in the nation's airport security
system, aviation officials told Congress on Thursday.


   The technology exists to detect contraband and weapons, but
operators must be carefully selected, monitored and trained, said
Alexis M. Stefani, an assistant inspector general at the U.S.
Department of Transportation.


   However, the people who operate metal detectors and X-ray
equipment at airports sometimes are replaced four times a year,
according to a study by the General Accounting Office.


   ``With regards to retention, I think it's obvious that we have
to keep people on the job longer,'' Cathal(cq) Flynn, the Federal
Aviation Administration's top official for civil aviation security,
told the House aviation subcommittee. ``At 400 percent turnover
rate, I think it's difficult to train people to sharpen pencils.''


   Despite the demanding nature of the job, Flynn said, the private
companies that provide security services for most airlines pay many
employees minimum wage. Sometimes the screeners leave to work at
airport fast-food outlets for higher pay and benefits, he said.


   The FAA is working on new rules that would require security
companies to be certified, Flynn said. It expects to make a final
decision on whether to implement the rule, which was suggested in
1996 by the White House Commission on Aviation Safety Security, by
May 2001.


   The administration will also use a new technology known as
Threat Image Projection (TIP) to measure the performance of
individual screeners and screening companies.


   TIP is a computer program that electronically inserts images of
contraband on X-ray and explosives detection system monitors,
making it appear that the material is inside a bag being screened.


   A computer-based training system to evaluate and train screeners
is also under study, Stefani said.


   The FAA hopes to install these devices and other equipment at
airports nationwide by 2003, he said.


   Even with better training and better pay, some members of the
aviation subcommittee said they feared screeners with criminal
backgrounds will be hired to handle passengers' luggage.


   The FAA now performs criminal background checks on screeners,
but it doesn't disqualify candidates who have been arrested for
such crimes as burglary, drug possession, arm robberies and assault
with a deadly weapon, Stefani said.


   ``It's just extraordinary to me that we let the system operate
in this way,'' said Rep. Peter A. DeFazio, D-Ore. ``Why have a weak
link in a sophisticated security system?''


   Ismail Turay Jr.'s e-mail address is ismailt(at)coxnews.com


   ENDIT


   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers


   For Use By Clients of the New York Times News Service

 No Charges Filed Over Schiavo's Bag 


	COLUMBUS, Ohio (AP) -- No federal charges will be filed against  
former inspector general Mary Schiavo, whose unaccompanied bag at 
the Columbus airport disrupted operations. 


	The bag, which was being used by Ms. Schiavo and a television  
station for a story on airport security, was found in a passenger 
area of Port Columbus International Airport on March 12. 


	Security officials took it to a runway, which they closed for  
about four hours while investigating. 


	U.S. Attorney Sharon Zealey said Wednesday that prosecutors  
could not prove that Ms. Schiavo acted with criminal intent to 
damage the airport. 


	A message seeking comment from Ms. Schiavo, former inspector  
general of the U.S. Transportation Department, was not returned. 


	Ms. Schiavo resigned from her federal post in 1996 after  
criticizing the Federal Aviation Administration on several 
occasions. She has since published a book accusing the FAA of 
sloppy inspections, lax airport security and disregard for bogus 
airplane parts. 


	In the Columbus case, she has said she attempted to put an  
unaccompanied suitcase packed with harmless items on a plane the 
day the runway shut down. 


	Ms. Schiavo has said she was hoping to determine whether the bag  
would be allowed to leave with the flight even though its owner was 
not on board. Bags are matched to passengers on international 
flights, but checks are not required for domestic passengers. 


	She said the bag was clearly marked with her name and address,  
and claimed that airport officials called the bomb squad to make a 
scene that would discredit her. 


	WCMH-TV reported that it had told airport officials it was doing  
a story on airport security. Station president and general manager 
Michael Jack said Wednesday that its news department was vindicated 
by the federal prosecutor's decision.

1996-03-22 16:16 
 American Allegation on Greece's Airport Safety  Problem Refuted 


ATHENS, March 22 (Xinhua) -- Greece today categorically refuted
American allegations that the security stands at the Athens
international airport was bad.


A recent U.S. report claimed that the security conditions at
Greece's Hellenikon Airport were ''among the three worst in the
world''.


Refuting the American allegations, government spokesman
Dimitris Reppas said ''the security conditions at the airport are
good''.


He added the problems at the airport were being dealt with.


The spokesman noted that the American report itself
acknowledged the efforts being made to improve conditions at the
airport and underlined that the report did not constitute a travel
directive.

results.content:
1999-01-28 
 HK New Airport Praised by Travel Agents and Media 


Reiterating Mr. Dale's comments, Ms Catherine Yeoh, director of
Reliance DWC (Canada) Inc, added "there is no doubt that Hong Kong
International Airport can be rated as one of the world's top
airports."


These praises were echoed by accolades from several members of
the international media visiting Hong Kong.


Mr. Lee Woo-chul, executive vice-president and senior editor
of the Travel Trade Journal (TTJ), one of the leading travel trade
publications in Korea, was delighted with his experience at HKIA.


Mr. Lee, who had also visited the airport before its opening,
said, "When I saw the new Hong Kong airport before it opened, I
had very high expectations of how spectacular a building it was
going to be, and I'm happy to say that my experiences on this trip
have more than confirmed those expectations."


Mr. Nik Walshe and Ms Jo Parkerson, news editor and presenter,
respectively, for the UK's Chrysalis Radio, were also in Hong Kong
recently. "It took us less than one hour between getting off the
plane and settling down in our hotel room. Immigration and customs
officers were very friendly, and the transportation service was
most efficient," they said.


These comments have been confirmed by an award won by the
airport earlier this month, as the media worldwide recognized the
HKIA's achievements and voted it the best airport in Asia Pacific
in the Journalists' Choice Awards.


The HKIA has also received a major international award from
the US-based Travel & Leisure magazine, in which it was voted
"Best Airport".


In addition, several recent surveys show that passengers' and
other users' levels of satisfaction with the airport's services
and facilities have risen substantially over the past six moths or
so.


The Airport Authority survey revealed that 92.6 percent of
users are satisfied with the services and facilities, with more
than one in three respondents giving them top marks.


In terms of security, the HKIA received high praise from the
U.S. Government's aviation safety regulatory body, the Federal
Aviation Administration (FAA), which commented that the overall
security at the HKIA is "excellent."


The FAA also said that security arrangements and practices
exceed guidelines set by the United Nations' International Civil
Aviation Organization.


The HKIA is confident that it will be a beacon for the ongoing
recovery of Hong Kong's tourism industry, said the HKTA survey
report.

results.content:
1997-04-11 
 First Italian Soldiers Arrive in Albania 


TIRANA, April 11 (Xinhua) -- The first batch of Italian
soldiers arrived in Albania today to spearhead a multinational
protection force that aims to secure the country's key harbors and
airports.


The 20-strong vanguard is charged with preparing the ground for
the arrival of the 6,000-strong force from six nations that is due
to start arriving on Monday. The vanguard reached the port of
Durres after sailing across the Adriatic from the Italian port of
Brindisi on Thursday evening.


It was followed by another group of 20 Italian paratroopers who
landed at Tirana airport half an hour later.


The advance unit is made up of engineers and marines, most of
whom had carried out missions in Bosnia.


The Italian-led multinational force was formed with soldiers
from Italy, France, Spain, Romania, Turkey and Greece after the
United Nations Security Council decided on its creation, on March
28. This is the first time Italy has led a multinational mission
since World War Two.


The bulk of the protection force will be Italian soldiers, some
2,000-3,000 troops.


The force's main task is to secure ports and airports, and
protect delivery of relief aid to the population of the Balkan
country.


The collapse in January of bogus investment schemes, in which
thousands of Albanians put their life savings, sparked protests
across the country which quickly spilled over into armed
insurrection in March.


The country has since been gripped by unrest and anarchy.
Protesters demanded repayment of their hard-earned money and the
opposition Socialist Party launched an outcry for the resignation
of President Sali Berisha.


In mid-March, Bashkim Fino, an economist from the Socialist
Party, was invited by the president to form a new government
which, in the following weeks, took effective measures to placate
nationwide unrest. It sought help from the European Union and the
Organization of Security and Cooperation for Europe.
