results.content:
MACHINES TO CHECK AIRLINE BAGS MOSTLY IDLE, REPORT SAYS 



   WASHINGTON _ The Federal Aviation Administration has spent more
than $122 million on machines to detect bombs in checked baggage,
but those machines that have been installed sit idle for most of
the day, according to investigators from the Department of
Transportation.


   The machines, which cost $1.3 million each to buy and install,
are supposed to be capable of handling 225 bags an hour, but of 13
that were audited by investigators, nine handled fewer than 200
bags a day, according to a report released on Friday.


   Some got so little use that the operators could not maintain
proficiency in running them, investigators said.


   ``At some airports, they're sitting relatively unused,''
Lawrence Weintrob, an assistant inspector general of the
Transportation Department, said in a telephone interview. ``Some
airports that are using them are using them rarely, or process
relatively few bags through them.''


   But Cathal Flynn, assistant administrator of the FAA for civil
aviation security, said the average number of bags processed
through each machine was rising sharply as airlines gained
experience. Flynn and airline representatives said that part of the
problem was that the computerized system for choosing which
passengers' bags get scanned was still developing, and would not be
fully implemented until the end of the year.


   ``We haven't ironed out all the kinks in the process,'' said
Susan Rork, managing director of security at the Air Transport
Association, the trade group of the major airlines.


   The computerized system singles out individuals about whom there
is too little information to conclude that they are not a threat,
officials say. It also draws a sample from the group judged not to
be a threat, to increase the chance that a terrorist would be
caught, and to make the system fairer, Flynn said.


   One problem, he said, is that if the system were changed to
require that a larger number of passengers have their bags
scrutinized, then at peak periods people would be delayed so long
they would miss their flights.


   ``If you get people fuming at a line, that's not good either,''
Flynn said. That, he said, would probably discourage machine
operators from doing their jobs right. And delays, he said, would
damage public acceptance of security measures.


   In written comments responding to the report, the FAA said that
the agency would ``pursue a more coherent strategy with air
carriers to ramp-up to a higher level of use.'' However, the agency
said, it would be ``many years'' before technology allowed
screening of all bags.


   Auditors also said that the machines in use could handle only
about half as many bags as they did in lab tests, partly because
they sound false alarms far more when in use at airports. Each
false alarm requires time to resolve. (All alarms so far have been
false, officials said, because no bombs have been detected.)


   The machines' higher false alarm rate is ``probably a reason why
they don't use it as often as they should,'' Weintrob said.


   Fifty-nine of the machines have been installed so far; plans are
to have 74 in place by the end of the year, he said.


   Officials of airports where the machines are installed declined
to comment and asked not to be identified. Under FAA rules, airport
operators are responsible for various aspects of security, but not
for screening bags. That responsibility falls to the airlines.

results.content:
1996-07-31 
 G-7, Russia Adopt 25 Measures Against Terrorism 


PARIS, July 30 (Xinhua) -- The Group of Seven (G-7) most
industrialized states and Russia today adopted a package of 25
measures to combat terrorism after a one-day conference on the
issue.


The practical steps include restriction of terrorists' freedom
of movement, control of fund-raising for terrorist groups and
improvement of exchange of information.


But a declaration issued after the meeting did not mention of
U.S. President Bill Clinton's call for economic sanctions against
Iran, Iraq, Libya and Sudan for their alleged support for
terrorism.


The foreign and interior ministers of the eight countries said
in a declaration forerunning the text that they "invite all states
to adopt these measures so as to impart greater efficiency and
coherence to the fight against terrorism."


The ministers call on all states to expand training of
anti-terrorism personnel, make sure of security of all means of
transportation, including mass transportation like train, bus and
subway trains and cargos transportation, and accelerate research
on methods to detect explosives.


All the countries in the world could adopt standard bomb
detection systems in their airports and passenger planes in
consultation with the International Civil Aviation Organization,
and to increase international cooperation in checking terrorism
through signing bilateral or multilateral treaties, the statement
said.


The eight countries urged all countries in the world to act
against any organization that supports terrorism, prevent
terrorists from using "electronic or wire communications systems
and networks to carry out criminal acts," and tighten control on
firearms.


They called on all states to "refrain from providing any form
of support, whether active or passive, to organizations or persons
involved in terrorist activities."


The ministers urged all countries "to take strong measures to
prevent the movement of terrorist individuals or groups by
strengthening border controls and controls on issuance of identity
papers and travel documents."


They also warned all countries against letting terrorists take
advantage of the right of asylum "for terrorist purposes."


They appealed for the exchange of information on "actions and
movements of persons or groups suspected of belonging to terrorist
networks."


Such information also includes the use of communications
technologies by terrorists and "the threat of new types of
terrorist activities including those using chemical, biological,
nuclear material and toxic substances," said the statement.


French Foreign Minister Herve De Charette announced at a press
conference today that a team of experts will be formed by the end
of the year to draft a new convention against terrorist bombings
and threats to public transportation.

results.content:
1998-02-09 
 Beijing Airport Security Confiscates 7,700 Pieces of Contraband 


BEIJING, February 9 (Xinhua) -- Latest statistics show that the
security department of the Capital International Airport in
Beijing confiscated 7,700 pieces of contraband in 1997.


Xue Xianzhong, vice-director of the airport security
department, said the contraband included 219 inflammable
materials, 427 side arms, 1,800 knifes and 17,000 rounds of
ammunition.


Public security officers also detained 1,804 passengers holding
fake or invalid passports, and arrested five wanted criminals.


The airport attempted to ensure the security of all passengers
by attaching the highest level of importance to related
services. Thirty information boards have been strategically placed
throughout the airport complex, with suggestion boxes and
telephone complaint lines providing better services to passengers.


Statistics show that public security officers helped
transient passengers recover property and cash valued at over
three million yuan.

results.content:
1997-03-02 
 Californian Airport Evacuates Passagers Scared by Toy Gun 


WASHINGTON, March 1 (Xinhua) -- About 1,000 travelers were
evacuated and at least 20 flights were delayed today at the San
Jose International Airport, California, scared by a toy handgun,
reports reaching here said.


Rosemary O'Kane, the airport spokeswoman, said, the evacuation
was caused after airport security reported a handgun in a backpack
brought in the airport.


Flights at the San Jose airport, located about 40 miles (64 km)
south of San Francisco, were put on hold for nearly three hours as
airport security searched for the weapon.


At last, security officials found that the alleged handgun
was a toy packed in a young boy's carry-on backpack.


The incident caused the postponement of at least 20 flights,
interfering with the travel plans of an estimated 4,000
passengers.

results.content:
1999-07-30 
 China's First Local Airport Administration Law 


SHANGHAI, July 30 (Xinhua) -- China's first local airport
administration law, the Regulations on Civil Airport Area
Administration in Shanghai, will take effect August 1.


The law was adopted by the Standing Committee of the Shanghai
Municipal People's Congress. It has stipulations on construction,
security, administration, public order, and environmental
protection in and around airports in the city.


A committee spokesman says that the law will greatly help
improve airport administration and the smooth operation of
airports in the city.


Shanghai's Hongqiao International Airport is one of China's
three largest international airports. Another airport, Pudong
International, is under construction in the Pudong New Area and is
scheduled to be operational by September. By that time, the city
will become the only city in the country with 2 international
airports.

results.content:
1998-09-09 
 Uganda Beefs Up Security at Airport: Police 


KAMPALA, September 9 (Xinhua) -- Ugandan police have beefed up
security at Entebbe International Airport following two telephone
threats to bomb the area, a senior police commander told Xinhua
Wednesday afternoon.


Chris Bakesiima, the central regional police commander, said
in a telephone interview that more than 100 policemen have been
deployed in the area to guard against any possible bombing.


"We will not leave anything to chance because of the recent
bus bombings in the country" which claimed some 30 lives and
injured many others, he asserted.


The police deployed at the airport in the southern city of
Entebbe have been on full alert since the threats were received.


A road block has been set up just two kilometers ahead of the
airport terminal to check every person and vehicle heading for
the airport.


The reinforcement of the police force will be there
permanently to take care of the area and the international
airport in particular, the police commander added.


Ugandan police have tried various means to sensitize civilians
on the dangers of suspicious objects and given tips on what to do
in every kind of emergency cases.

results.content:
Israel threatens to close Palestinian airport over security


	   JERUSALEM (AP) _ Israel has threatened to close down the
Palestinian-run Gaza airport over a security violation, an Israeli
official said Tuesday, a move that could further undermine the
already fragile peace process.
	   Palestinian airport workers refused to allow Israeli security
officials to check the identity of passengers who arrived on an
Egyptian plane Sunday afternoon, most of whom worked for the
Palestinian Authority, according to Civilian Airport Authority
Director Nir Yarkoni.
	   ``The Transportation Minister asked me to tell the Palestinians
that if this continues, we won't allow the airport operate,'' he
told The Associated Press.
	   Yarkoni said he conveyed the message in a letter Monday to
chairman of the Palestinian Civil Aviation Authority Brig. Gen.
Fayez Zeidan.
	   Zeidan was not immediately available for comment.
	   Israel retains security control over flights arriving to Gaza
International Airport.
	   The airport's opening last month, stipulated by the accords
brokered by U.S. President Bill Clinton at Wye River, Maryland in
October, was hailed by Palestinians as a milestone toward
independence and statehood.
	   Since then, Israel has accused the Palestinians of failing to
contain anti-Israel violence, and has frozen the accords. The
Palestinians, in turn, accuse Israel of reneging on an agreement to
release Palestinians jailed for anti-Israel activities.

results.content:
Israel threatens to close Palestinian airport over security


	   JERUSALEM (AP) _ Israel has threatened to close down the
Palestinian-run Gaza airport over a security violation, an Israeli
official said Tuesday, a move that could further undermine the
already fragile peace process.
	   Palestinian airport workers refused to allow Israeli security
officials to check the identity of passengers who arrived on an
Egyptian plane Sunday afternoon, most of whom worked for the
Palestinian Authority, Civilian Airport Authority Director Avner
Yarkoni said.
	   Yarkoni conveyed the warning in a letter sent Monday to the
chairman of the Palestinian Civil Aviation Authority Brig. Gen.
Fayez Zeidan. A copy of which was made available to the Associated
Press.
	   ``The Minister of Transport, after consulting the Prime Minister
and the Minister of Defense, instructed us to bring to your
attention his very stern warning that repeated violation of the
(airport) protocol will prevent us from letting you to continue the
operation of the airport,'' Yarkoni said in the letter.
	   Israel retains security control over flights arriving to Gaza
International Airport.
	   Zeidan said that Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat and his
entourage were aboard the plane in question _ condition, he said,
that exempted the plane from Israeli security checks under the
protocol.
	   ``The Israeli side has nothing to do with the inspection of Mr.
Arafat's aircraft,'' Zeidan said, adding that Israeli security
officials at the airport complained only that they were not allowed
within the customary 30 meters (yards) of the plane to visually
inspect the disembarking passengers.
	   ``I don't think it's a reason to close the airport,'' Zeidan
said. He said he was investigating the Israeli claims.
	   The airport's opening last month, stipulated by the accords
brokered by U.S. President Bill Clinton at Wye River, Maryland in
October, was hailed by Palestinians as a milestone toward
independence and statehood.
	   Since then, Israel has accused the Palestinians of failing to
contain anti-Israel violence, and has frozen the accords. The
Palestinians, in turn, accuse Israel of reneging on an agreement to
release Palestinians jailed for anti-Israel activities.

results.content:
First Palestinian commercial flight to Amman makes round trip


	   DAHANIEH, Gaza Strip (AP) _ The first Palestinian commercial
flight to Amman took off Saturday, inaugurating an air route
between Jordan and the newly opened airport at the autonomous Gaza
Strip.
	   The Falcon F-50 short-haul plane carried 48 passengers, mostly
Palestinian businessmen and students and returned to Gaza
International Airport later in the day with a full plane load of
travelers.
	   Both the takeoff and the landing of the return flight were
delayed due to Israeli security demands. Although the airport is
operated by the Palestinian Authority, security is jointly handled
with the Israelis.
	   The Palestinians consider the airport, which opened last week,
as their first gateway to the world, a strong symbol of fledgling
independence. The airport opened after more than two years of
disputes between Israel and the Palestinians over security
arrangements.
	   Adel Imad Abu Ali, 29, a Palestinian student studying for his
MBA at Amman University said security delays would not dissuade him
from flying on the Palestinian airline.
	   ``When you pay even one penny to the Palestinian airline it
means that you are participating in building your state and you are
guaranteeing a future for yourself and your children,'' Abu Ali
said as he boarded the flight to Amman.
	   Landing at the Gaza International Airport was a dream come true
for Nassar Arriadui, 45, a Palestinian-born businessman who lives
in Jordan.
	   ``When I saw the airport tower as we landed I thought that I was
dreaming,'' Arriadui said.
	   Jasser Ziyyad, director-general of the Jordanian Civil Aviation
Authority, said Jordan agreed with the Palestinians earlier in the
week on four weekly flights between them _ two by the Palestinian
airline and two for Jordan.
	   Meanwhile, Jordanian newspapers quoted unnamed Palestinian
aviation officials as saying one more passenger plane will be added
to the Palestinian fleet of three short-haul aircraft.
	   It said the addition was necessary to transport an estimated
3,600 Palestinian Muslims who wish to travel to Saudi Arabia in
early March to perform the annual pilgrimage to holy shrines in
that country.

results.content:
Israel threatens to close Palestinian airport over security


	   JERUSALEM (AP) _ Israel has threatened to close down the
Palestinian-run Gaza airport over a security violation, an Israeli
official said Tuesday, a move that could further undermine the
already fragile peace process.
	   Palestinian airport workers refused to allow Israeli security
officials to check the identity of passengers who arrived on an
Egyptian plane Sunday afternoon, most of whom worked for the
Palestinian Authority, Civilian Airport Authority Director Avner
Yarkoni said.
	   Israel, which retains security control over flights arriving at
Gaza International Airport, maintains the move violated an
Israeli-Palestinian security protocol.
	   Yarkoni conveyed the warning in a letter sent Monday to the
chairman of the Palestinian Civil Aviation Authority Brig. Gen.
Fayez Zeidan. A copy of the letter was made available to the
Associated Press.
	   Yarkoni said in the letter that the transportation minister,
after consulting with the prime minister and defense minister,
``instructed us to bring to your attention his very stern
warning,'' and that repeated violations will ``prevent'' Israil
from allowing the airport to continue operation.
	   Zeidan said that Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat and his
entourage were aboard the plane in question, and he said that
exempted the plane from Israeli security checks under the protocol.
	   ``The Israeli side has nothing to do with the inspection of Mr.
Arafat's aircraft,'' Zeidan said, adding that Israeli security
officials at the airport complained only that they were not allowed
within the customary 30 meters (yards) of the plane to visually
inspect the disembarking passengers.
	   ``I don't think it's a reason to close the airport,'' Zeidan
said. He said he was investigating the Israeli claims.
	   The airport's opening last month, stipulated by the accords
brokered by U.S. President Bill Clinton at Wye River, Maryland in
October, was hailed by Palestinians as a milestone toward
independence and statehood.
	   Since then, Israel has accused the Palestinians of failing to
contain anti-Israel violence, and has frozen the accords. The
Palestinians, in turn, accuse Israel of reneging on an agreement to
release Palestinians jailed for anti-Israel activities.

results.content:
1999-05-28 
 China to Implement "Security Check Regulations for Civil Aviation" 


BEIJING, May 28 (Xinhua) -- China will implement the recently
issued formal "Security Check Regulations for Civil Aviation" on
June 1, a measure affecting all plane travelers in the country.


The set of regulations, which will guide and standardize
airport security checks, defines in details the rights and duties
of passengers and cargo owners, according to Ma Songwei, an
official with the General Civil Aviation Administration of China.


Ma said the regulations also will provide greater convenience
for passengers.


This is the first time clear and definite guidelines have been
spelled-out relating to carried or consigned shipments and the
number of objects passengers are allowed to carry.


China's civil aviation began security checks in 1981 and issued
tentative regulations in 1992.

results.content:
1998-04-07 
 Bomb Hoax Sends Harare Airport in Panic 


HARARE, April 7 (Xinhua) -- Eighty passengers on board of a
South African Airways (SAA) Airbus flight from Johannesburg were
detained for several hours at Harare International Airport on
Monday for security checks following a bomb hoax, the Zimbabwe
News Agency reported Tuesday.


Harare airport officials said they received a call from the
captain of the SAA flight which said one of the passengers was
believed to be carrying a bomb.


All passengers were detained in the local domestic terminal
while they identified their luggage during security checks.


Police and bomb disposal unit with sniffer dogs were used
during the operation.


All security personnel were deployed on full alert. Plain
clothes officers cordoned off the airport and patrolled around
both terminals and waiting lounges.


Harare International Airport Manager Karikoga Kaseke confirmed
the incident, saying it had been a hoax.


The captain of the SAA flight received information on his way
to Harare from his company that a certain female from Durban had
telephoned the SAA in Johannesburg that his flight from
Johannesburg to Harare was carrying a bomb, Kaseke said.


"The flight was already mid-air and the most logical thing for
the captain to do was to proceed to Harare and he informed us of
the bomb threat some 35 minutes before landing," said Kaseke.


Kaseke said all rescue and fire tenders were summoned to be on
standby including those from government service.


The bomb disposal unit made a detailed search of the plane for
almost an hour and nothing was found, he said. The plane was
declared safe by 13:30 hours, after a further check, Kaseke said.


In 1996 a tipsy South African national was arrested at the
airport for claiming he possessed a substance for making
explosives.

results.content:
1996-07-20 
 U.S. Demands Tighter Security by Hungary 


BUDAPEST, July 20 (Xinhua) -- The United States has asked
Hungary to tighten security for its personnel and properties
following the crash of the TWA flight near New York.


The local press said Hungarian police were now taking emergency
measures to step-up airport security checks for stop-over
U.S. flights, and for U.S. institutions including its embassy.


The TWA (Trans World Airlines) Flight 800 bound for Paris from
New York killed all 230 on board on Thursday when it crashed off
Long Island.


The U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation is conducting a
"criminal investigation" of the explosion on the flight, and has
not ruled out terrorism as a cause.


It was reported that Russia also asked Hungary to provide
better protection of its personnel and properties because of a
possible threat from the Chechen rebels.

results.content:
1996-11-29 
 Late Nigerian Security Chief Identified 


LAGOS, November 29 (Xinhua) -- The Nigerian police have
identified the chief security officer of the Lagos international
airport, Sola Omotsola, who was killed in a car bomb recently, as
an anti-government agent.


The official "New Nigerian" reported today that investigations
by security operatives on the incident revealed that Omotsola and
his cousin Nelson Kassim, who was also killed in the bomb, were
sabotage agents working for the anti-government National
Democratic Coalition (NADECO) led by Wole Soyinka.


The discovery is rather a shock to the police, who suspected
that the bomb was planted in the chief security officer's car by
a sabotage agent.


Speaking to reporters yesterday in Lagos, police airport
commander Alhaji Mohammed Abubakar said that Kassim was believed
to carry the bomb on his lap on their way to the airport when it
exploded, tearing himself and the car into pieces.


Dring a search of Omotsola's office in their airport, the
police found four detonators already connected, two radio
frequency ignitors, four kilograms of dynamite explosives, a roll
of cellotape used for plastering the bomb and a nine-volt dry
cell battery.


The searchers also seized a bag containing Kassim's passport,
computer spare parts and a radio frequency counter.


Omotsola's colleagues said he was always conscious of the
security of his office, to the extent that no one had the key to
his office while he was alive, and that his office was never
cleaned without his presence.


Abubakar said Kassim has been confirmed by security agents as
a computer technologist with vast knowledge in bomb making.


Omotsola, 50, has a doctorate in criminlogy. He was a Nigerian
American and was invited to the Lagos airport by Nigerian
authorities in 1984 from the J.F. Kennedy Airport, the United
States, where was a chief security officer.


He was killed with his cousin on November 14, when his car
exploded on the way to airport.

Israel delays two flights from Palestinian airport


	   JERUSALEM (AP) _ Israeli security officials delayed two planes
from taking off from the Palestinian airport on Wednesday, the
latest tensions in a rare area of Israeli-Palestinian cooperation.
	   A plane bound for Amman, Jordan was delayed for two hours over
an Israeli demand that Palestinian officials inspect the luggage of
a Palestinian passenger, Israel radio reported. The plane left with
the passenger aboard, but without his luggage.
	   Israeli officials also delayed a plane making a stopover from
Saudi Arabia to Cairo, it said. Israeli airport security officials
were not available for comment.
	   Abdel Razek Yehia, a Palestinian official who helped negotiate
the airport's opening, confirmed the delays. He said such
differences did not undermine the peace process.
	   ``Every day we have differences,'' he told The Associated Press.
``We are all doing all our best to continue the peace process.''
	   The airport's opening last month, stipulated by the accords
brokered by U.S. President Bill Clinton at Wye River, Maryland in
October, was hailed by Palestinians as a milestone toward
independence and statehood.
	   Israel retains security control over flights arriving at Gaza
International Airport, and Palestinian security officials consult
with their Israeli counterparts.
	   Earlier this week, Israel threatened to close down the Gaza
airport when Palestinian airport workers refused to allow Israeli
security officials to check the identity of passengers who arrived
on an Egyptian plane, most of whom worked for the Palestinian
Authority.
	   Palestinian officials said that Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat
and his entourage were aboard the plane in question, and that
exempted the plane from Israeli security checks.
	   Since Wye, Israel has accused the Palestinians of failing to
contain anti-Israel violence, and has frozen the accords. The
Palestinians, in turn, accuse Israel of reneging on an agreement to
release Palestinians jailed for anti-Israel activities.
	   (rk)

results.content:
Report: Plane robbed by gunmen in Nigerian airport 


	   LAGOS, Nigeria (AP) _ An Air Afrique Boeing-727 jet was the
third passenger liner looted in the past month by armed robbers
while awaiting takeoff at Nigeria's largest international airport,
the Lagos Guardian newspaper reported on Thursday.
	   The thieves broke into the aircraft's luggage compartment and
escaped with a large quantity of baggage as the plane was awaiting
permission to take off from the Lagos international airport control
tower around 9 p.m. on Tuesday night, the Guardian said. It was not
clear where the airliner was destined.
	   There was no immediate confirmation of the report.
	   The plane's captain, who noticed the theft, sent a distress call
that went unanswered by airport officials. Security personnel on
duty later said said they were unable to capture the culprits
because their only security vehicle had been taken away for routine
maintenance.
	   In another incident last week involving an unidentified
passenger jet, landing gear worth dlrs 1 million was stripped from
while the plane was waiting to take off, the newspaper said. In
May, a Cameroon Airlines plane was robbed of its luggage after
armed thieves blocked the plane on the tarmac with a large log.
	   The robberies came despite orders from airport security
officials to shoot suspected thieves on sight.
	   Nigeria, Africa's most populous country, has a notoriously high
rate of violent crime accompanied by a breakdown of law and order
under years of military rule.
	   (fa-gam)

2000-05-29 
 Venezuela To Hold World Airport Security Meeting 


CARACAS, May 29 (Xinhua) -- An international meeting on airport
security will be held here Tuesday, the official paper "Venpres"
said Monday.


Attending this event will be delegations from Colombia,
Argentina, Guatemala, Costa Rica, Honduras, Peru and El Salvador,
as well as representatives of the U.S. embassy in Venezuela.


Among matters that will be discussed at the encounter stands
out the human factor in physical security and training of
personnel in inspection and control questions.


Effective and ingenious solutions from the economic viewpoint
for improving standards of physical security, technological
advances for equipment inspection, airport design and aspects of
physical security will also be seen, among others.

results.content:
2000-03-06 
 Nepal Denies Indian Security Presence at Airport 


KATHMANDU, March 6 (Xinhua) -- The Nepali Foreign Ministry
denied that Nepal has agreed to allow the presence of Indian
security personnel at the Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) in
Kathmandu as reported Saturday by the French news agency AFP, The
Kathmandu Post reported Monday.


Foreign Secretary Murari Raj Sharma told the English daily that
the news was not true. "The news holds no truth. Nepal has not
entered into any agreement with India," he said.


AFP quoted Indian Minister of State for Civil Aviation Chaman
Lal Gupta as saying Saturday that "Nepal had admitted of security
lapses at its international airport and had agreed in principle to
allow India security at the TIA," the report said.


The English daily also quoted a highly placed official at the
Home Ministry as denying that there has been any kind of agreement
regarding TIA security between Nepal and India, not even in
principle.


A Home Ministry source ruled out the possibility of India's
posting their security at TIA, saying India has not sent any team
here to discuss the issue as reported by AFP.


After an Indian Airlines passenger plane was hijacked on route
from Kathmandu to New Delhi on December 24, 1999, India has
suspended its flight here and suggested posting security personnel
at TIA, which was rejected by the Nepali government.

results.content:
AIRPORT INCIDENT RAISES CONCERNS ABOUT `AIR RAGE' 



   A violent incident at Newark, N.J., International Airport that
left a Continental Airlines gate agent near death and a passenger
under arrest has led to a wave of protest among airline workers who
say they have been increasingly targeted by aggravated, aggressive
passengers in the phenomenon known as ``air rage.''


   The gate agent, Angelo Sottile, 50, of Kearny, N.J., suffered
fractured spinal vertebrae and head injuries on Thursday night when
a passenger who tried to enter a jetway without a boarding pass
became enraged, picked the agent up and hurled him head-down onto
the floor, Port Authority police said.


   While the passenger, John Davis, 29, of Fredericksburg, Va., was
arrested and charged with aggravated assault, and Continental's
management met with employees twice on Friday to discuss security,
many of Continental's 11,000 Newark workers remain uneasy over
dangers posed by belligerent and sometimes drunken passengers
angered by flight delays, cancellations and other problems.


   ``People's attitudes have changed,'' Timothy Peterson, 34, who
has been a Continental baggage handler for five years, said
Saturday at Newark's Terminal C, where the confrontation occurred.
``They are aggravated with long lines and flight delays. They're
becoming more aggressive. People lash out, scream at ticket agents.
I'm concerned for my personal safety.''


   Continental officials insisted Saturday that security for its
49,300 employees across the nation was of paramount concern, and
that attacks by unruly passengers would not be tolerated. ``We will
not stand for any violence against our employees,'' said Catherine
Stengel, an airline spokeswoman. ``The safety of our employees is
very important to us.''


   Ms. Stengel noted that Continental, like other airlines,
provided security at the airport, along with the Port Authority
police, but she acknowledged that the security was not specifically
focused on the protection of employees, and she declined to discuss
the adequacy of the security.


   Gordon Bethune, chairman and chief executive of Continental, the
nation's fifth largest airline, noted in a message to employees on
Friday that Sottile had been grievously injured and pledged to
protect workers and to prosecute anyone who assaults them.


   ``It's really sad when things like that happen, and we're going
to make sure, to the full extent of the law, that the customer who
took that action against one of our employees is prosecuted,''
Bethune said. ``We love our customers, but that means they have to
respect our employees.''


   Port Authority police said that Sottile was working in Terminal
C at Gate 115 on Thursday night, preparing to board passengers for
a flight to Orlando when, at about 9:10 p.m., a toddler ran from
his parents in the waiting area into the jetway leading to the
aircraft.


   The child's mother, accompanied by a Continental gate agent,
went into the jetway in pursuit. The child's father, identified as
Davis, also tried to enter the jetway, but he was barred by Sottile
because he had no boarding pass _ his family had not yet picked
them up from the ticket agent at the gate.


   Davis, the police report said, became enraged at Sottile, picked
him up in a bear-hug, turned him upside down and hurled him,
head-first, onto the floor. Sottile suffered several fractures of
the spine and neck, as well as head injuries.


   Davis walked away, but was seized nearby by Port Authority
officers, who handcuffed him. Meanwhile, an ambulance was called,
and Sottile was taken to University Hospital in Newark, where he
was listed in critical but stable condition Saturday.


   The suspect was charged with aggravated assault and, after an
arraignment in Essex County Court, was held at the Essex County
Jail in $50,000 bail. He was released Saturday after posting bail,
officials said.


   Upset by the incident, Continental employees at Newark _ many of
whom are unionized, though not the gate agents _ demanded meetings
with the airline's management on Frida

results.content:
Opening of Gaza airport marks emotional day for Palestinians


	   DAHANIEH, Gaza Strip (AP) _ Thousands of Palestinians watched
breathlessly as the first Palestine Airlines flight touched down at
Gaza International Airport Tuesday and crew members waved the
national green, red, black and white flag from the pilot's window.
	   And then, with many holding back tears of joy, the emotional
crowd began a spontaneous celebration of dance and song set to last
for days. The opening of their first airport was a concrete sign
for Palestinians that their lives were becoming freer and their
homeland was moving one step closer to statehood.
	   ``The meaning of the airport is freedom and the feeling that you
are a citizen in a country,'' said Shaban Khalil, a 47-year-old man
from Gaza City.
	   Gaza International, built with dlrs 75 million in contributions
mainly from Japan, is petite for an international airport. Sprawled
over 1,125-acres, it has one runway long enough to accommodate all
but the biggest jumbo jets. The one passenger terminal for arrivals
and departures resembles an Arabian desert palace with arches and
multicolored Moroccan tiles and includes a VIP lounge.
	   In the first weeks, airport operations will have to rely on some
improvisation. Major pieces of equipment, including the controls
for the control tower, are still at the Israeli port of Ashdod.
Tuesday's planes were guided to a safe landing by a portable
control panel installed in a van.
	   Israel, which feared a solely-Palestinian run airport would mean
enemies could land at its door-step or smuggle weapons to the
Palestinians, held up the opening for two years over security.
	   Under the airport agreement, Israel will continue to control the
airspace and could shut down the airport at any time. With a
full-time but discreet monitoring presence there, Israel will
pre-approve all flight schedules and passenger lists. No Israeli
will sit in the control tower or operate any area of the airport.
	   Tuesday, Israeli and Palestinian security agents greeted an
Egypt Air flight and collected the passports of the passengers,
including Egyptian Cabinet ministers in small white bags.
	   As of Wednesday, Palestinian officials say no Israeli presence
will be visible. Arriving passengers will be transferred by buses
from the planes to a security check area in the airport where they
will go through metal detectors. Palestinian agents will X-Ray
luggage and cargo while Israeli monitors observe the security
checks from behind one-way mirrors, as they do now at two other
crossings into autonomous Palestinian areas.
	   If Israel disputes an inspection, the passenger and his luggage
will be taken to a separate area where Israelis will carry out an
additional check while Palestinian agents observe.
	   Palestine Airlines, which already runs a twice-weekly flight to
Jordan from a small airstrip in Egypt, will now operate out of Gaza
International. The brand-new national carrier is starting out with
a fleet of three planes including a Boeing 727 _ a gift from a
Saudi prince.
	   The airport will also be the permanent home of Yasser Arafat's
presidential plane. A giant portrait of the Palestinian leader hung
from the control tower for the festive opening Tuesday and Arafat
was on hand to personally greet seven plane-loads of dignitaries.
	   ``This is a preparation for the declaration of the Palestinian
state,'' Arafat said, smiling broadly and flashing a V sign.
	   Next month, U.S. President Bill Clinton is expected to land
there too _ giving implicit recognition for independence, at least
in Palestinian eyes
	   Tuesday's opening was a dramatic event in the history of the
Palestinian people. Despite the monitoring role, the airport marks
a significant loosening of the Jewish state's security grip over
the Palestinians. Years of requests for Israeli permission, often
denied, to travel anywhere by land or air are slowly ending. For
people in the cramped Gaza Strip which is surrounded by barbed-wire
on three sides and the sea on a fourth, the airport will provide
the only

NEWS STORY 
 2000-01-01 14:42 
 Diaz Target of Airport Crime  


    LOS ANGELES (AP) -- An airport security checkpoint wasn't very secure for
Cameron Diaz, who walked away from the scanners minus $7,000 and her passport.


	   A security guard operating an X-ray machine at Los Angeles International
Airport was arrested for investigation of grand theft on Thursday after Diaz
noticed the cash and her passport missing, said airport spokeswoman Nancy
Castles.


	   A surveillance videotape showed the guard taking the items from Diaz's
purse, Castles said. The stolen items were recovered.


	   The guard's name was not immediately released. She worked for a private
company that operates the X-ray machines.


	   Diaz starred in "There's Something About Mary" and currently co-stars in
"Any Given Sunday."

results.content:
1996-08-17 15:11 
 Syrian Prime Minister Visits Iran 


TEHRAN, August 17 (Xinhua) -- Syrian Prime Minister Mahmoud
Zouebi arrived here today on an official visit, the first in six
years, amid stepped up U.S. sanctions against Iran.


Greeted by Iran's First Vice-President Hassan Habibi at the
airport, Zouebi said that Syria would like to boost its political,
economic, technical and cultural relations with Iran.


Described the present relations between the two countries as
excellent, he said he flew to Tehran to "consult with the Iranian
leadership on regional and international issues."


Zouebi is accompanied by six cabinet members including the
ministers of industries, economy, transport and education.


He is expected to hold talks with Iranian President Hashemi
Rafsanjani Monday.


Official sources said that Turkey's proposal on a
quadrilateral meeting of foreign ministers of Iraq, Turkey, Syria
and Iran to discuss the situation in northern Iraq would be among
the topics to be discussed in the course of Zouebi's visit.


Talks were held on the issue between Iranian and Turkish
leaders when Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan visited Tehran
early this week.


Now the Iranian and Syrian leaders would focus on measures to
end the internal belligerence in Iraqi Kurdestan, to prevent the
disintegration of Iraq and confront the presence of foreign powers
in the region, the sources said.


It is unclear if the two sides will also assess the
U.S. sanctions against Iran. Reporters were given little time to
ask the Syrian prime minister for comment at the airport.


U.S. President Bill Clinton signed the D'Amato bill into a law
to punish Iran and Libya on August 5 for alleged sponsoring
terrorism.


Syria, Iran's ally in its eight-year-old war against Iraq, is
believed to be carefully seeking better ties with Washington in
anticipation of securing an Israeli withdrawal from the Golan
Heights.

1996-08-17 15:17 
 Syrian Prime Minister Visits Iran 


TEHRAN, August 17 (Xinhua) -- Syrian Prime Minister Mahmoud
Zouebi arrived here today on an official visit, the first in six
years, amid stepped up U.S. sanctions against Iran.


Greeted by Iran's First Vice-President Hassan Habibi at the
airport, Zouebi said that Syria would like to boost its political,
economic, technical and cultural relations with Iran.


Describing the present relations between the two countries as
excellent, he said he flew to Tehran to "consult with the Iranian
leadership on regional and international issues."


Zouebi is accompanied by six cabinet members including the
ministers of industries, economy, transport and education.


He is expected to hold talks with Iranian President Hashemi
Rafsanjani Monday.


Official sources said that Turkey's proposal on a
quadrilateral meeting of foreign ministers of Iraq, Turkey, Syria
and Iran to discuss the situation in northern Iraq would be among
the topics to be discussed in the course of Zouebi's visit.


Talks were held on the issue between Iranian and Turkish
leaders when Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan visited Tehran
early this week.


Now the Iranian and Syrian leaders would focus on measures to
end the internal belligerence in Iraqi Kurdestan, to prevent the
disintegration of Iraq and confront the presence of foreign powers
in the region, the sources said.


It is unclear if the two sides will also assess the
U.S. sanctions against Iran. Reporters were given little time to
ask the Syrian prime minister for comment at the airport.


U.S. President Bill Clinton signed the D'Amato bill into a law
to punish Iran and Libya on August 5 for alleged sponsoring
terrorism.


Syria, Iran's ally in its eight-year-old war against Iraq, is
believed to be carefully seeking better ties with Washington in
anticipation of securing an Israeli withdrawal from the Golan
Heights.


However, visits by senior foreign officials at this sensitive
moment were seen here as of great political importance since they
might help offset the U.S. efforts to isolate the Islamic
Republic.


During this visit by the Syrian prime minister, Iran and Syria
will sign an economic cooperation agreement in a bid to remove
double taxation and establish joint trading firms.


The agreement will also cover Iran's technical assistance to
Syria in the fields of silos, railway network and steel industry.


"We have comprehensive program and list of issues to
discuss. We hope to reach agreement during Syrian delegation's
stay in Tehran," First Vice President Habibi said.

results.content:
1999-08-03 08:30:26 
 financial 
 Larceny Up at Busiest Airport 


	FORT WORTH, Texas (AP) -- High-tech security abounds at airports,  
but nothing can separate a passenger from his property quicker than 
a short attention span. 


	``Most people that are victims -- God love 'em -- weren't paying  
attention. They left their suitcases behind while going to the 
bathroom or they asked someone else to watch their baggage, or they 
left jewelry behind while they were washing their hands,'' said 
Avry Dodson, who as director of the Department of Public Safety 
oversees Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. 


	``People are leaving valuables in plain view,'' said Benjamin  
DeCosta, general manager of Hartsfield Atlanta International 
Airport. 


	Most airport security is focused on major breaches, such as  
terrorism. The amount of crime at the nation's airports is not 
monitored by any federal agencies unless it has a special relation 
to aviation safety. 


	``Security is through the Federal Aviation Administration, but  
that's oriented only to terrorism and contraband goods that 
threaten flights,'' said Bill Mosley, a spokesman with the 
Department of Transportation. 


	The airlines do report mishandled baggage, which could be  
stolen, but otherwise ``street'' crime is considered a local issue 
and not monitored on a national level, he said. 


	Instead, law enforcement concentrates on the trends it finds in  
its own backyard. 


	At Hartsfield, the world's busiest airport with about 73.5  
million passengers annually, larceny is the crime of the year. 
According to police statistics compiled by The Atlanta 
Journal-Constitution, theft has climbed 26 percent for the first 
four months this year. 


	Car thefts also have gone up, doubling from 107 in 1997 to 215  
last year. 


	A 9 percent increase in passenger volume could be partly to  
blame for the rising thefts, but DeCosta said he's investigating 
whether a theft ring is canvassing the airport. 


	At D-FW, missing vehicles are the bigger problem.  


	``In the last year we had 180 vehicles stolen from rental  
agencies,'' said Dodson. ``These are not random thefts. Most of 
these are employee related. We recover over 80 percent of the 
rental cars that are stolen.'' 


	Airline employees also have sometimes been the issue when theft  
occurs. 


	This April at D-FW, 10 baggage handlers were arrested for  
stealing property from about 500 bags bound for flights on American 
Trans Air, British Airways, Korean Airlines and Lufthansa. 


	In 1998, a group of baggage handlers at American Airlines in  
Miami were arrested after a 19-member special security team did a 
sting operation. The 44 baggage handlers were accused of pilfering 
thousands of pieces of jewelry, electronic equipment, cameras and 
cash from inside suitcases as planes arrived and departed. 


	But those aren't the majority of theft cases; much of the  
stealing is done right in front of the passenger. 


	Earlier this year at D-FW a man was charged with habitually  
stealing those black-wheeled bags that look similar to dozens of 
others on the baggage carousel. 


	His modus operandi was to steal the common-looking bags and  
plead ignorance if stopped by the rightful owner. 


	``The guy had been making a living out here,'' said Dodson.  
``He'd been stopped by people but always bluffed his way through.'' 


	Altogether, he pirated about $1 million of loot to sell at flea  
markets and a couple of warehouses full of stuff before he was 
caught. 


	Airports in New York have a much bigger problem with pickpockets  
than many other cities and police have conducted several sting 
operations to catch regular thieves, according to Bill Cahill, 
spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. 


	Meanwhile, Chicago O'Hare International Airport, which handled  
72.5 million passengers last year, seems to have the most trouble 
in its bathrooms. 


	Thefts in airport restrooms have risen 99 percent at O'Hare as  
most property crimes decreased. 


	One thing that is rare at airports

results.content:
Conference on Africa's Airports Opens in Cairo 


CAIRO, September 11 (Xinhua) -- The annual Africa Regional
Conference of the Airports Council International (ACI) opened here
today with the participation of some 140 airport representatives
from 39 countries in Africa and other parts of the world.


The participants representing airports, airlines and
international organizations from Africa and around the world would
exchange views on ways to upgrade facilities and services of
Africa's airports to ensure a secure and reliable air transport
system in the continent.


With the promotion of Africa's exports and the development of
its tourism, airports are playing a more and more important role
in the economic development of the region. The two-day conference
will review the African airports' readiness to act as a catalyst in
Africa's development.


The ACI-Africa Region includes 39 members running 128 airports
in 36 countries. The ACI has a total of 440 members running some
1,200 airports in 150 countries.

results.content:
1999-10-18 
 Sri Lanka Trains Maldivian Airport Personnel 


COLOMBO, October 18 (Xinhua) -- Sri Lanka is to continue
training Maldivian airport personnel at its Civil Aviation
Training Center, press reports said Monday.


The superintendent of the center T.R.N. Perera told the
official Daily News that Maldivian airport's security personnel
have already been trained here.


He said another batch of fire personnel from the Maldives
Airport Authority is due in Sri Lanka within the next few days for
training.


The center, established by the Airport and Aviation Services of
Sri Lanka in 1984, aims to provide specialized training for
certain categories of its own personnel.


So far the center has trained 19 batches of security personnel
totaling about 550 persons for the Bandaranaike International
Airport in northern suburb of Colombo.


To expand its training program, the center proposes to purchase
an air traffic control simulator to train air traffic controllers
who are at present trained abroad.
